Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I have completed this book for you, my sons, which is the last one concerning knowledge in medicine with its supplement, and after I have reached the end of it through explanations and declarations of the same, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise, which constitutes a part of operation or surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since operation with the hand is laid low in our region and is completely absent at our time; until perhaps the knowledge of it has perished and its trace has vanished; and only minor descriptions of it remain in old books, which have been altered by hands; and errors and hesitations occurred until the intentions were closed and the force waned: It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise according to the way of positioning, declaring, and abbreviating; and that I should come with patterns of iron instruments of Cautery and other tools of work; which is done by adding declarations and by properating what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a good craftsman with his hand is not found in this our time is that the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy as narrated by Galen, until he knows the means of limbs, their shapes, their connections and disconnections, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, their number, their origin, the pulse vessels, and the quiet ones, and the locations of their exits.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And because of this, Hippocrates said that name with name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 We have already spoken about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 Since he who is not knowing what we have said about anatomy, will already fall into error, in which people are killed: just as I have seen many of those who are formed from this science and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 I saw a foolish surgeon cut an aposteme on the neck of a woman and accidentally cut some arteries in her neck. Consequently, blood flowed from the woman until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 I also saw another surgeon who presumptuously attempted to extract a stone from an elderly man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 Therefore it came to him, and he extracted the stone with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Therefore, the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 I myself had already been called to extract it; and I saw from the size of the stone and the weakness of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 I saw another surgeon who was receiving a fee from one of our land's dukes on account of medicine; and a black eunuch who was with him suffered a fracture near his heel; and the surgeon, in his ignorance, tightened the fracture over the wound with splints, pulley irons, and strong bands; and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he closed it according to his own devices.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Afterwards he released him after a few days and ordered him not to undo the bandage; and it remained like that until an aposteme formed on his leg and his foot, and he came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 I was called to him; and I hastened to undo the bandage; and calmness came upon him, and he was relieved of his pain.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 But the corruption had already been confirmed in the limb; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Stop the corruption from spreading through the limb until it perishes.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous boil; and it was opened after days, until the wickedness of it with its master (the cancer) was revealed.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 Because when a cancer is pure from black bile, then it should not be reached with iron at all unless it is in a member that can bear it, so the entire thing may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And because of that which is said in the Gospel, "You shall know them by their fruits," it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation that brings salvation; and the operation, with which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already warned in every place of this book where the operation comes that has fear and terror.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to be careful about it and separate it from itself so that fools do not find a way to speak and disgrace themselves.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Therefore receive the measurement with care and protection, and treat your weak ones with ease and firmness, and use the better way that leads by the grace of God to salvation and praiseworthy success; and abandon the terrible ailments difficult to heal; and free your souls from what makes you fear, so hesitation in faith and comfort enters over you.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to the quantities of yours.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 Galen has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not heal the evil ailment; lest you be called evil physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters. ¶
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On Cautery with fire and with sharp medicine, Chapter arranged, and ordered from head to foot, and forms of instruments and iron tools of Cautery; and all that is necessary for the operation. ¶
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter second.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 On incision and perforation, bloodletting and ulcers, and wounds; and on the removal of arrows and similar things; and on the entire chapter, arranged according to the forms of instruments. ¶
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter third.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 On restoration and dislocation, and treatment of twisting and similar conditions; the chapter arranged from head to foot, and according to the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 On the remedy and harm of cautery; on which conditions it is applicable, and at what time; and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 Before I remind you of the operation with him, it is necessary that I say the quality of his remedies and his harmful effects, and in what composition they are presented.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I say therefore, that the discourse on the quality of the cautery, and its harmful effects, is a long, subtle, learned discourse, full of secrets and hidden things.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Moreover, a multitude of wise men spoke about it and disagreed on it: and to me, their discourses are enough, fearing protraction.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I say therefore, that the cautery applies universally to every composition, whether with matter or without matter; except for two compositions, which are the hot composition without matter, and the dry composition without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 In the hot and dry composition with matter they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 For some, it was said that the cautery is beneficial in the hot and dry composition with matter.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite of this, namely that the cautery is not suitable for the disease which is from heat and dryness; because the nature of fire is heat, and it is inconvenient to heal from a disease of heat and dryness with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who says the opposite of this said that by the cautery there is benefit in every disease of heat and dryness which happens in human bodies; because when you compare a man's body and his humidity to the composition of fire, you find a man's body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I myself say through his discourse; because it has often been proven to me that.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 Nevertheless, it is not necessary for it to be brought up unless he who has already been proven and has been exercised in the chapter of cautery exercise at the end, and knows the diversity of human complexions, and the disposition of diseases within themselves, and the causes of them, and their characteristics, and the space of time of them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 From the remaining humors, there is no fear for you; and especially in cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For indeed, all physicians have agreed upon them (the cauteries), and they have not disagreed about using the cautery with them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, my sons, that from the secret of cure through cautery with fire and its goodness upon the cautery with medicine burning, because fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the part being cauterized; and it does not harm another member joined with it unless slightly.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of burning medicine reaches to that which is separated from the limbs; and perhaps it causes difficulty in healing the disease in the member, and perhaps it kills it.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 Fire however, because of its subtlety and goodness, does not do that unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 But indeed that has been made known to us by experiment, because of the length of service and study with art, and steadfastness on truth; and because of that I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not, because it is not permitted for this book of mine to disclose the secret hidden in fire and the quality of its operation on bodies in expelling diseases, which I would demonstrate through a philosophical discourse that would become clear to your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, my sons, that they themselves disagree on the time when a cautery should be made, and place the better time in truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that a cautery is suitable at all times; therefore, any harm resulting from time is submerged in the benefit attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if a cautery is for pain resulting from necessary pains, strong, sharp ones which cannot tolerate delay; therefore, it is feared that an evil greater than slight harm may occur through the passage of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let that thought not slip from your minds, O sons, that which is not deemed true except by the vulgar and foolish physicians, namely that there is no return for the sickness that is cured by cautery; and they set forth this consequence, but it is not so as they think: because cauterization is only in place of medicine, which alters complexion, and expels the humidities that are the causes, why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 Nevertheless, cauterization is unnecessary over medicine due to the swiftness of its own vitality and the efficacy of its operation, and the intensity of its dominion: it is possible that sickness may return at some hour according to the constitution of the sick person, the location of his sickness, and the potency of his illness; and what is prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluities within him; and what comes to him through consumption of food and similar things due to the causes, unless there arises a sickness in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A subtle sickness in a member of few superfluities and humidities, such as cauterization of the tooth, due to pain and similar things, it is possible that that pain will not return in him.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 But this happens in rare cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 But indeed the speech of the vulgar is correct again, that cauterization is the last medicine: it is not intended for what they intend in this matter; because they believe that there is no cure that is given with medicine nor with anything after the disappearance of cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But it is indeed the opposite of theirs and their intention that cauterization is the last medicine; this is not so except when we administer modes of cure for a sickness and those remedies do not confer; then at the end of the matter, we apply cauterization and it confers; then it follows that cauterization is the last medicine, but not according to the intention which the vulgar and many foolish physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that a cautery with gold is better than a cautery with iron; and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold and the loftiness of its substance; and they said that it does not cause pus in the place of the cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 This is not always true; because I have already proven that it does not do this in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And a cautery with it (gold) is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 However, when you apply fire to cauterize it (gold) in fire from gold, it is not made clear to you when it burns according to the quantity you wish, due to the redness of gold; and when it approaches the same cold, and if you add more heat to it, it melts in the fire and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore, the craftsman falls into it (gold) in confusion; and because of this, we make a cautery with iron among us more quickly and closer to the operation, for its rightness.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 And I myself have now arranged this chapter on cautery, according to the chapters; and I have arranged it from head to foot so that those who seek something from it find what they want.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing at the junction of the skull (coronal suture).
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 Here is the cauterization for mastery over humidity and coldness on the brain: these two are the causes of soda, and the abundance of flow of humors from the head to the parts of eyes and ears, and the abundance of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain; and universally all illness that occurs due to coldness, such as paralysis, sodae, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar ones due to illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is to instruct the sick person: to evacuate firstly with purifying medicine for three or four nights, according to the strength of the sick person, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to rub his head with a sponge (or soft cloth).
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then make him sit facing your hands, so that he has placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that place with a charcoal (or other non-burning substance).
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then heat the cautery oil: whose shape is this.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then place it on the marked place with charcoal, and you gradually press your hand down, and turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then lift your hand quickly and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that a piece of bone or wood has come out from the skull, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, continue to press with the iron itself, or with another one if it becomes cold; until the bones that I told you are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take some salt, and dissolve it in water, and immerse the cloth in it, and place it on the place; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place upon him a cloth soaked in butter, and let it remain until the burn is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with four-ingredient ointment, until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 It has been said that the longer a wound remains open, the more pus it discharges; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 Some have said that the skin should be cauterized to the bone; and hold the cautery until it burns something of the thickness of the bone.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then scrape off the burned part of the bone after that, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 Some say that when the cautery is reached to the bone, it should be pressed onto the bone for as long as an impression of a knife blade is made, so that the bone falls away, forming a hole like a scar: or the instrument which women put in place, filled with vinegar: and they think that vapors from the head escape through this place, and leave the wound open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then treat it until it is healed and solidified.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But I do not see these two types of cautery at all, except in some people, according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And leave it alone, in my opinion, it is better for its own sake.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 For the head becomes weak from the solution of its own continuity; just as we have testified in other members; and especially when the head is naturally weak; and the first species of cautery is safer and better for me, and I use it: operate therefore with it for the benefit.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the head in pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	 Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When there is a chronic pain throughout the head and it persists in a weak person, and they use warm things, and poultices, and sweating, and oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 If already cauterized with one cautery, as we have said, and adds nothing of those [other substances]: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 If the head of the sick person is strong by nature and not weak, and it finds a very intense cold: then cauterize with another cautery slightly under that one.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize it on top of all the horns of its own head with another cautery, so that the skin is not pierced and the quantity of bone exposed, as we have said.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 Then cauterize it with one cautery on the occiput of its own head, in the place which is called 'vas': and this is the place where the sinus is placed: and grind your oil in that, and do not expose the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the sick person finds an intense pain there, different from the pain of all other cauteries of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I say this Cautery in its place: it is necessary that it be a cautery for the horns of the head and the occiput more delicately with the cautery for the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for hemicrania, both with hot medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When there is pain and swelling on a part of the head or it extends to the eye, and the head is treated with cleansing medications, and the rest of the treatment is given as I said in the divisions of diseases, but it does not help completely: then cauterization is done in that according to two methods: either cauterization with a burning medication: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cautery with a burning medication is as follows: take one tooth from an almond and grind it, and cut off the ends of it from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then cut open the place of pain at the time with a large lancet, until there is a space under the skin where a tooth can be taken.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Introduce it into the same place under the skin until it is covered; then bind it on top with a small bandage of appropriate tension, and leave it for fifteen hours; then dissolve it, extract the garlic, and leave it for two or three days; afterward place a warm cloth soaked in butter over it, until a pus forms; then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to do this with some burning medicines mentioned in my treatise on Medieval Remedies, the Twelfth Book.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 Cauterization of it with iron, is according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 Fire-cauterization, whose form is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 It is called Clavilus: because the head of it is like a nail, in which there is something hard and in the middle of it is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the location and hold your hand; and you turn the iron slowly with speed; and let the quantity that is heated be according to the thickness of the skin, as much as half of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And lift your hand, so that the artery which is below is not burned, and let there be a flow of blood.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then soak the cloth in salt water, and place it on the location, and leave it for three days; then put the cloth with butter; afterwards care for it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this half-cranium with the tip of a second cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 Caution: avoid cutting the artery in this half-cranium, not an old one properly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in an old half-cranium.
Caput V.	 Head V. (The Latin numeral 'V' indicates the fifth head or section.)
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you treat a hemicrania, as we said in the previous treatment and what we said in the divisions of diseases, and the treatment does not improve: and if you observe from the disease that what we said with the first cautery with medicine, or with cautery with fire, is insufficient, then it is necessary to heat the cauterium with a small knife (cultellare), until it becomes white after marking the place of pain with a line, whose length should be half a finger, or about that: and place your hand on one side, and tighten it so that you can cut through the artery, and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 However, you must be careful not to burn the jawbone, which moves during chewing, so as not to burn the side or the nerve that moves it, thereby causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And take care, and be cautious about bleeding from the artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 Indeed, fear of this (bleeding) is great, and especially for those who are unaware of what it does, and not diligent or experienced: and they abandon the operation first with it.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I will come again when reminded of the regulation for controlling bleeding from an artery according to its method and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 If you observe from the disease that this cautery is insufficient and if you see a weak body tolerating the cautery in the middle of the head as we said, treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery as we said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cautery having two small knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 For this reason, cauterization is better and more effective in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing ear pain.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When pain occurs in the ear due to coldness and is treated with solvents, and with the remaining treatment as we said in the division, and the pain does not go away, then cauterize it with fire (Cautery). This is what is called a Punctum, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then the puncture points, after its ignition around the entire ear, as it is revolved; or around both, if the pain is on both sides.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And move the cautery slightly from the root of the ear after you have marked the places with wax; and let the amount of cautery be ten punctures in every ear, and approximately so.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then care for the places until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 \ paragraph on the method of cauterization in Torture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 Torture that is treated with cauterization, is not other than those afflictions that occur due to phlegm, as we said in the division of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And avoid cauterization for the species that occurs due to exhaustion and spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you treat this species of torture with hyssop, purges, gargarisms, and your treatment does not improve, then it is necessary to cauterize the weak one with three Cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little below the eardrum, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the weaker side.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Because softening does not occur unless on the healthy part.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the form of cauterization is to cauterize itself with the cautery on the edge of the upper part of the ear, slightly below the horn of the head; and another one at the eardrum; whose length should be according to the length of a thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 Place your hand with the cautery until it burns to a depth of half the thickness of the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 This is the form of a cautery and it is of the type of scissors, whose shape is as follows: nevertheless, it should not be too delicate, as you see; and it is necessary that the scissors are in it of only slightly excessive thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then take care of the places with it, until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When apoplexy occurs and your care and the medicine I mentioned do not help, and the patient does not have fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head, as described before, and another cautery at the back of the head, according to what was described earlier: and the method of cauterization should be as described earlier.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Also cauterize with a cautery on the mouth of the stomach; and this is more of an emergency measure.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then care for it with what was described earlier.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in oblivion.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that there are in the drink firstly large amounts of hyssop, and purifying pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave the head of the sick person entirely, and place on his head an ointment made from syrup described in the book of ointments; put it there several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For this is the method of cautery; make it according to the same order as I have said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If he recovers through that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not: then perform three cauteries on the back of his head, which shall descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; place between each cautery a thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then care for the cautery, as with that which has come before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If you wish an additional treatment, and the sick person can bear it: then perform a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 And if you wish an additional treatment: then cauterize him over two horns [temporal regions].
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then care for him until he is cured; let the cautery be anointed according to the form that has been given.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 [Chapter heading] On the method of cauterizing paralysis and softening it.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed with the mundification of the head with hyson, and with what has been said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then scrape the head of the sick person; afterwards, cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over all the horns of the head, and with a cautery over the back part of it, and with three over the spondyles of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If however you need softening for the disease of the body with more of those [medicines], and the person is weak, and the disease is strong: then cauterize it with four cauteries over the spondyles of the back, and the last one with a cautery, until it is burned through most of its skin, and loosen your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then take care of him, until he is healed; and thus cauterize with oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 Section on the method of cauterizing for epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 A epileptic is not cauterized unless his epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you first cleanse the brain of him (the patient), especially during hyers (feverish conditions), and with the rest of the treatment as we have said in the division: when the sick person is severe or endures well in the administration of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 If (the patient) is a child who cannot endure medicines, then gargarisma (a solution or ointment) and cleansing chewing substances for the brain are given before many days with good food provisions.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with a single cautery on the middle of the head, as has been described before; and cauterize again on the nape of his neck, and over all the horn (of the skull) with cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If the sick person is strong and endures well, then cauterize him with the cauteries as has been described in the presence of paralysis, and mollification of the body on the spondylus (a type of bone) of the neck and back; and let the cautery be oiled as described before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If the sick person is a child, then place a subtle cautery (tool) according to this method:
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the causes of melancholy are corrupted humidities and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries, which we said in the one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of decline towards melancholy and the body is wet, then give him to drink what purifies his brain, as was said in the division: then shave the head of the sick person, and make afterwards a well-centered plaster made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it in the middle of the head: and the sick person sitting squarely should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then bring the linen.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 It is more appropriate from ancient sheep's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it over fire with a suitable temperature measurement, which the finger can bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle and let it go until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this to the sick person once a week with the rest of his good regimen, until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures on him, in addition to holding the cautery in your hand: let it be fragrant.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cauterization moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place a wick soaked in butter or chicken fat on him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in water that falls to the eye.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When the beginning of water appearing in the eye is shown to you through the signs that I said in the division, then begin and give the sick person something to drink, with what cleans his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 Keep him away from all moistness, and have him sit in a bath, for several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then command him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize him on two temples with two cauteries, if there is blockage of water flow in both eyes at the same time; or from one side, if there is blockage of water in one eye: and cut with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in width equal to the temples: and avoid bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see something coming out of him, then immediately cut it off with any medicine that is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting off and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries produced at the end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 Chapter on the ancient method of cauterizing in tears.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 If the tears of the eyes are old and persistent, and are above veins and arteries that are clearly visible on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is due to excess cold phlegm: then cauterize with the same cautery as I described in the blockage of water flow, cauterize in the middle of the head, and on two temples with two cauteries, and in the neck under two bones with two cauteries.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if it requires additional treatment, then cauterize him on all sides of the eye carefully, near the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in nasal fetor.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it, as we said in division, and the medication does not help: then hurry, and give to drink infirmocochias for three nights; afterwards shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium cautery, with the cautery oiling.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Afterwards cauterize him with two cauteries and a clavius cautery, over the two eyebrows under the hair slightly.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And beware of the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the form of the clavius cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for the softening of an eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of an eye is softened due to disease or dampness: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it over the two eyebrows slightly in every place with two cauteries; and they should extend from the two temples; and let the length of all the cautery be, according to the length of the eyebrows; and do not bring your hand with the cautery to the ends, but rather according to the quantity that is burned by the third eyelash.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing an eyelid when the hairs turn and pierce the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The cautery is used in this in two ways: either with fire, or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 In the cautery with fire, command the sick person to let go of his hairs, if he is one who combs them, until they are extended and evened out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 If they pierce him at his origin: then bind the eyes with adhesive so that they do not move until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When therefore they are born and have equalized, then place the head of the sick in your lap: afterwards mark on the eyelids of his eyes with hot wax, mark what is in the shape of a myrtle leaf; let the beginning of the mark be near hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then put a wet cloth on cow's milk or slippery elm on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat an iron for cauterization, which has this shape.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize step by step on the spots marked in many places until the surface of the skin burns entirely like the shape of a myrtle leaf, appearing completely.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And your mark of healing is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and hairs rising at the spot of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then lift up your hand at that time; and let it go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then put a wet cloth with butter on it over him until the wound heals.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is well.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If any hair comes back from the hairs after an hour and the eyelid softens: then repeat the cauterization on that spot as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If however there are hairs below it: then cauterize that spot until the hair is raised to its own natural position and it becomes equal so that the hairs do not touch the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 You must command the sick to shave his head until they grow and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make from paper in linen the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from soap known and uncooked lime from one pound each or similar; then grind them well with a good pestle and make it quickly so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then take a piece from that [substance] and place it on the cloth you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and put it on one or both eyelids.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And place under the eye a cotton soaked in egg white; let the head of the sick person be in your bosom.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 Place your index finger on the medicine and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 You should move [the medicine] whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While the pain persists that he finds, then release the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the pain subsides, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 Then observe if the eyelid rises, as it does when contracted by fire or incision, that is good; and if not, then apply more medicine to the place where the medicine does not press, and does not discolor, until your work is equalized and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place cotton with butter on it until the skin burns are removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with diaphinicon ointment or another until he is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the operation to keep the last guard, so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes soft after days and something from hairs falls into the eye, then apply more medicine to the place that becomes soft from the eyelid, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him until he is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore your consideration should be according to this: and the straight path for which there is interest in this art should not be hidden.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 On the method of cauterizing in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	 De modo cauterizandi in fistula lachrymalis.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat a Fistula, and your treatment does not alleviate the condition as I have described in the divisions of diseases: then, it is necessary that you cauterize it in this manner.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Command the sick man to place his head in your lap, and let him hold his own head by his hands thusly, so that he does not move or shake it with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then place a cotton soaked in warm oil or psyllium poultice on his eye; then cauterize it with the iron of this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 Let it be concave, like the shape of a goose feather quill from one end, for making a cautery; and if you wish it to penetrate to another end, and if you wish it to extend upward in this way.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, this concave shape is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then squeeze the fistula if it is open and draw out the pus from it, and cut it; and if it is not open, then open it and draw out its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place on it the cautery which has been heated very well.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand near the cautery for a moment at the eye, at the nose part, so that your hand does not wander or the sick man is disturbed; and you will place the cautery on the fat of the eye, and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If, therefore, you reach the beginning of your cautery up to the bone, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice, as needed; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then place cotton with butter on it, and treat it with an ointment of resorcinol until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 If it exceeds forty days and does not heal: then place a sharp, corrosive medicine on it until the bone appears; and shave it according to what comes under its own chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method of cautery for fistula, which some of the first ones said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Apply to the location of the fistula, and find it; then place upon it a fine cannula, that is, a fine tube, whose shape this is [diagram].
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 Pour into it [the cannula] a quantity of drachmae of melted lead, and hold your hand with good retention of the tube, and let the weak one not move at all, so that the melted lead does not run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary that you place over the weak one's eye a cloth soaked with infused oil, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the location of the fistula and heals it by marvelous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula is healed along with what we said from cautery, and cure, it is good [outcome].
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 If not, then it is necessary to make an opening in the nose and lead the fistula back to the flow of the nose, according to where it will come out for itself [in its proper place].
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	 Chapter XX [chapter number twenty].
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 It frequently happens that fissures occur in the lip, which are called Pilae, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 Therefore, when you treat these fissures, along with what we said in the division of diseases, and cure does not help, then apply small hot cautery in the shape of a knife, according to this form [diagram].
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its concavity be according to the fineness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place it quickly into the fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with caerote until it is healed [or cured].
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in a fistula of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess happens at the root of the gum or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts; afterwards it becomes old, and pus runs and becomes a fistula; then take care of it, and do not apply treatment to it, if then it does not heal, it is necessary that fire cauterize it according to its size, which can enter the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then introduce the heated iron into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches its depth and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then take care of it afterwards with what I said about treatment until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If the pus separates and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place, and remove the corrupt bone according to what comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 § On the way of cauterizing in softened gums and teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums become soft due to moisture and the teeth move, and treatment with medicine does not help; then place the head of the weak person on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then apply fire cautery whose form will come later; it should be so that you place the reed on the tooth; and insert the heated cautery into it quickly: and hold your hand briefly, until the weak person feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And lift your hand; then apply the cautery again as often as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then the weak person should fill his own tooth with brine water and hold it for an hour; then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 The tooth moves and hardens, and the softened gums tighten and dry up the corrupted moisture.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 On the method of cauterizing tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	 Caput means chapter or heading, and here it refers to Chapter 23. So, the translation is: Chapter 23: On the method of cauterizing tooth pain.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When tooth pain is due to coldness, or there is coldness itself, or worms, and cure with medicine does not help: then cautery in it should be done according to two methods: either cautery with butter; or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The cautery with butter is as follows: take butter and boil it in an iron cauldron or in a copper one.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then dip the instrument in it and apply it to the affected area.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then immerse the instrument in boiling butter and place it quickly on the painful tooth and hold it until it cools down; then repeat this process several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 If you prefer, immerse linen or a cloth in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth; then place hot iron on top of it until the heat reaches deep into the tooth socket.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 The cautery with fire is as follows: prepare an iron or steel tube (canula).
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 Make sure the tube has a certain thickness so that the heat does not reach the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then apply the heated cautery to the tooth and hold it until it cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Repeat this process several times as pain will disappear either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 It is necessary to fill the hole left by cautery with good butter and keep it for an hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Apply cautery with any suitable tip according to your convenience; and this is the shape of the tube (cannula).
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 Method of cauterization in ulcers.
Caput XXIIII.	 Of the Cautery.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When sutures are covered in phlegm and cold moistness, and are not obeying digestion through medicines, and desire swift digestion: then, to a concave Cautery of fire, whose form is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open ends so that the smoke may exit at the Cautery from one end; and place it heated upon the ulcer once, and again, if needed, until it reaches the depth of the ulcer.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the ulcer is small: then place the Cautery according to the size of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then leave it for three days, and place upon it a hot cloth soaked in butter until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then take care of it with tooth ointment until the hole heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 Method of cauterizing in the hoarseness of voice and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When wetness collects on the windpipe and especially when it is accompanied by cold complexion, then the sick person should be evacuated first with dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize it at the neck near the root of the throat at a depressed place; and beware, do not reach the throat with the Cautery or skin, unless something of the latter is there.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it with another Cautery at the junction of the neck and the last rib of that juncture; and let the Cautery be a nail according to the method described earlier.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with what was described before until it heals.
