¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 On the method of cauterization during blood flow from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 Many times blood flow occurs from an artery that is cut at a wound caused externally, or at the incision of an abscess, or cautery of a member, and similar things: and it is difficult to separate it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 Therefore, when that occurs to someone, then immediately put your hand on the orifice of the artery and place your index finger over it: and press very hard, until the blood is trapped under your index finger, and nothing escapes from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place in fire small oil-filled cauteries, and many numbered ones: and blow over them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one, either small or large, according to the wound and place where the artery is cut, and place the cautery on that vein, after you quickly remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the blood is severed.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If the blood is expelled with the removal of your finger from the opening of the artery, and extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly, from those prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Do not cease to do this one after the other until the blood is severed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And beware lest you burn the nerve that is there, and further harm comes upon the weak through your carelessness.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to sever it: especially if the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we said before.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or by extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is extracted, the ends of it contract and the blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or it may be tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or medicine of the property for severing blood may be placed upon it and tightened with a decent tourniquet.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 Whoever administers the severing with a ligature and a tightening with a cloth, or by placing on it things that burn and similar items, does not greatly benefit him except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 If this happens to anyone and the physician is not present nor medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the opening of the vein as we said before, and constrict it very tightly until the blood is besieged from above the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 Do not remove the finger, always place cold water on it of great coldness until the blood freezes and it swells and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And meanwhile consider for it what requires cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 Chapter First Ends.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 The Second Book of the Surgeon Albucasis.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 On incision, perforation and phlebotomy in wounds, and similar things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 We have said in the first chapter that every sickness in which it is fitting to burn with fire and medicine, as well as its occasions, causes, instruments and forms of cautery.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And there I placed chapters from top to bottom.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 And I shall proceed in this chapter along the same path: to clarify what is sought for him who seeks it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that, my sons, it is necessary for you to know what is in this chapter from fear of that which is in the first chapter on cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And because of that it is necessary to be more cautious in this, for the operation which is in this chapter often causes evacuation with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or incision on an abscess, or opening of the passage, or cure of the wound, or extraction of the arrow, or incision on a stone, and similar things: from all of which are associated trembling, fear, and death occurs in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you not to fall into that which is hesitation, for sometimes those of this art fall into it as do the weak ones.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 For there is one who becomes angry with his sickness and death is light upon him because of the great danger which he finds from his weakness and the length of his misery.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And when sickness is from fear, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And of those who give their trumpet and tell you to come with them, hoping for health, the sickness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 Therefore it is not appropriate to agree with him who comes to you from those whose way is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Let your caution be greater than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume about anything from that, unless after certain knowledge, which is verifiable by the succession of praiseworthy outcome in you where it has arrived.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And treat all your sick with prognosis and direction to that which suitably is health for them.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For in that there is help for you in the acquisition of reputation and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 God will inspire you, O sons, with His wisdom, and not take away from you guidance and inspiration; for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And indeed I have organized this Chapter dividing it into sections, according to what came before in the chapter on Cautery, from neck to feet; so that you may be relieved of what is sought from him and what is needed by you.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 Chapter on the Treatment of Water Accumulated in Children's Heads.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 You should know that this affliction often occurs in children at childbirth, or when the midwife presses the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 And it sometimes happens also for hidden reasons which are not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And I myself have not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and death followed all whom I saw from among them for that reason; therefore it seemed to me that the operation should be abandoned in such a case.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And I myself have seen a child whose head was full of water and his head swelled every day until he could not sit on himself due to the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture, or collects between skin and bone, or collects beneath the bone above the nose.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And the operation on it, if there is moisture between skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then a split should be made in the middle of the head, one incision in width; and the length of the incision should be like two knuckles, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of trepanation (spatium means "hole" or "space", here referring to a surgical procedure involving drilling or sawing a hole in the skull).
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If the moisture is more increased and the abscess is larger, then place these two incisions according to this form (i.e., make a larger split in the manner described).
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see openings of the skull from all sides, and water is pressed out when you press it with your hand toward the inside and it does not hide itself from you; then it should be split in the middle of the head with three incisions according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after the incision, remove all the moisture entirely.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then tie the incisions with cloths and bandages.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then anoint it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then dissolve the suture, and treat the wound with poultices and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not let the head be tightened equally.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 Feed the sick person with dry food of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another mode of incision is to consider where it appears that the abscess is larger and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Because sometimes there is more in the head or skull, or in the right or left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore ascend with the incision where it appears to you that there is an abscess and filling of water, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And observe, do not cut the artery, and let not the blood flow out and the sick person die from that flow with evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 [Section on Incising Arteries after the Ears]
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When catarrh happens to someone's eyes or chest and it becomes chronic and medical treatment does not help: then the final cure is more in that, incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when you are about to cut them (the arteries), let the sick one shave his own head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the sick one tighten his own neck with any of his own cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then consider where the vein pulsates.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the places of both (arteries) are the places that are depressed behind the ears and they are rarely hidden unless in certain people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark each one with wax on both sides: and cut each one with a pair of forceps on both sides, the incision reaching to the bone: and make it in the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you wish, insert a pair of forceps under the artery and cut it above with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 And let the length of the incision be as long as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when the vein is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which jumps to the internal parts with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 If however, the artery does not appear to sight, then it is necessary that measurements from the ear determine the length of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with wax and cut to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And what must be released from blood is six ounces, perhaps you may release more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 The whole thing should be done according to the quantity that appears to you from the strength of the sick one and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 If there remains any flesh on the bone in the wound, then cut it so that no abscess of heat forms: then bind the wound with linen rags.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When an old hemicrania or acute catarrh occurs in a man due to acidic humidities and heat in the temples, or old sores, violent and similar ones: and it is treated with the modes of cure of medicine, but it does not help: then we have experience in dealing with such diseases by extracting arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method of operation in the extraction [of the artery], is that the sick person shaves the hairs which are in the temples, and stretches to appear the artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 Indeed it is shown to you by its pulse, and it is rarely hidden except in a few men or in case of violent coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden to you, then the sick person should tighten his head with any cloth of his, then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or apply warmth to the place with hot water, until it appears to you in an obvious manner.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take a thin piece of metal, which I have made a little earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then remove the skin with it easily, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then insert a hook into it and pull it out towards the top until you extract it from the skin, and make it come out from all parts of the layers beneath it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If the artery is subtle: then turn it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut off a part according to its length so that its ends can be stretched and contracted, and there is no bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 Indeed, if it is not cut and if it is not severed, the blood does not rise deeply.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then remove six ounces of blood until the third [?].
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large: then it must be tied in two places with double thread, strong, of silk, or with horsehair, so that putrefaction does not come to it before the wound heals and there is bleeding.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut off the redundancy which is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this at that hour, or another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a small cautery: until its ends are cut off and it remains in place for the same operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 It is a better work, unless if the patient has fever, or has been heated in composition.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because cautery is of those which help to end moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it is better aid.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the extraction of the arteries, let the place be filled with old cotton: and fine powdered charcoal be placed on top of it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after the solution, it will be cured with dry medicines that cause flesh to grow, and with linen until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation if there is a bleeding from an artery, then hurry to cut it off with a cautery, or fill the place with wax: and press your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If there is nothing from these present for you, then place your finger on it until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And bandage the place with water of intense cold, until the sharpness subsides and it is compressed as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And from what is lighter and easier to extract, the vein, it is that you cauterize with this cautery having two small blades: and the sharpness of the two blades is like a needle.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 However they are much less sharp than two blades.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Because if they are as sharp as two blades, then cold is required for both of them: and they do not cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Since therefore there is a certain thickness in them, heat is required in them, and the flesh is cut quickly with this: when this work is better than any other, and lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between two knives be the size of a finger's width, after you mark two places with wax: and place both very hot ones until they reach the bone, and cut through veins in two places: to dislocate what is between its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 They are not solidified entirely with this cautionery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of a cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 On the treatment of chronic sharp course of tears from eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When there are chronic tears with a course from the veins that are outside the skull of the head: and no remedy medicine is applied to them with medicines, and you see the face of the sick person turning red, and feels like a crawling sensation on his forehead, as it happens with ants: and his eyes are tired, wet, so much that the hair of their eyelashes has been corroded with corrosion: and his eyelids have been heated due to the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients used this treatment for them, and they called it the cure, with the knife.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is, that you instruct the sick person to shave the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then cut three slits in the forehead, equal to each other according to its length: and the length of the fissure shall be like two fingers, and one fissure shall be equal to the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second one slightly less than the movement of the arms, and the third on the other side: and be careful not to cut the arteries that are in the sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two jaws, and the space of all the incisions shall be the size of three joined fingers: and prepare for yourself a piece of sponge or dry cloth with which you can absorb blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a probang (spatula) with two sharp ends, which soon follows its form.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the incision on the temple side, up to the second incision: and remove with it the entire skin that is between the two incisions, together with the sifac, which is over the eye.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then make this also from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then extract this probang and insert again another tool called a sharp knife, blunt on one side and not sharp on the other side, into the first incision.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place the sharp side towards the attached flesh with skin, and the blunt side towards the bone; and push it so that it reaches the middle fissure; and cut with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes; except that the incision should continue up to that which appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then make this in the middle fissure up to another fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And when the amount of blood that flows is equal, press the places from the clots of coagulated blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place a linen cloth from old clothes in each fissure, and put on top of them little woolen balls soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And see to it that no abscess becomes hot.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 And on the third day, dissolve the ligature and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of this with a basilicum ointment and the rest that are used to heal wounds; until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 [Section heading: Treatment of sharp tears and catarrhs affecting the eyes from internal parts of the head]
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone gets sharp, intense, persistent catarrhs; and you see their eyes weakened, small, and the vision is already diminished; and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out from them, and there is intense pain deep in the head that hurts and follows sneezing: then take from these symptoms, those materials and catarrhs do not come unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 A better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it is to be commanded the sick one to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly off-center by width, and begin the incision from the left temple to the right temple: let the incision go as deep as bone: and withdraw your hand from the temples that move during chewing: until when the bone is exposed: and dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate the two lips of the incision with heated iron or with linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then tie up above with threads: and soak the threads with wine and oil, so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you release it (the wound), and see that the hot abscess is already beginning to diminish: then it is necessary that you scrape the bone, until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then take care of it with a drying dressing that promotes the growth of flesh: as if you were taking two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: prepare an ointment from these, and apply it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 Section on treatment for that which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four species: either a mineral stone, or something similar to a stone such as iron and ivory; or it is from a plant, such as chickpea and beans; or it is liquid, such as water, vinegar, and similar things; or it is an animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 When a stone falls into the ear, or anything similar to a stone that does not grow within the ear, reveal only the ear: if you see a stone, then pour something from violated oil, or sisamo into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer its extraction, and make him sneeze with a snuff, and open the nostrils near the coming of the sneeze, after you place around the ear fragments from cloths or wool, and stretch the ear towards the upper part.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 Often it goes out with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not go out, then administer its extraction with Geister, that is, fine Pizigaroli: whose form is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If it goes out with Geister, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer its extraction with a fine blind hook in small quantities several times.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If it does not go out through this, then make a tube of brass and insert the end of the tube into the ear opening very much, and open what is around the tube with softened wax with oil, so that there is no windway except the tube: then pull it out with your strong force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 Often it goes out with what we have said.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If it does not go out in this way: then take from helkalimbat or from vinegar, that is, gluten prepared like birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the radius after you have placed the cotton centrally positioned: then insert it into the ear opening with ease, after you have removed the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 If therefore it does not discharge with all that I have described, then hurry to cut before a hot abscess or a spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 The method of lancing is that the unwell person should first be lanced in the head: and draw out from the blood according to its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the sick person sit between your hands and turn his ear towards the upper part; lance a small fissure in the base of the ear at the fatty tissue in the depressed place there: and let the fissure be lunar shape until you reach the stone: then remove it along with it, as far as is possible for you using your tools.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then lance the fissure at your hour and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If what falls into the ear is one grain that grows and swells: then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not obey you to discharge, then take a thin, delicate instrument in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And administer with it the removal of that species from grains falling into the ear and do not do this when you think that the grain is already wet from earwax, until you put on many pieces: then remove them with tweezers or a delicate instrument or with suction, as we have said; for the removal of it is allayed.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 In water that enters the ear, the sick person should use sneezing with drying in the first place: and already his ear has been filled with a little hot water; and it lies above the one where there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If therefore it discharges through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if not: then take many small stones of the length of a finger, soft, warm and heat them slightly; and the sick person should insert one from these into his ear canal: and salt one foot on that side and hit with another stone on the stone in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 The translation is: "Therefore, it should not cease to be made with stone and stone, until all water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 "Thus the water comes out like this, that you take one from birchwood or from reed and insert one end into the ear; and heat the other end with fire until it burns as much as possible.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 "Then take another reed and do the same many times until all water comes out; and draw it out with a probe according to what was mentioned above in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 "In the extraction of an animal entering it, if it is of small body, like a louse, and similar to what was mentioned above in division, take care of it as I said.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 "But if it is of large body, which appears to the sense; then administer the extraction of it with forceps and hooks; and its removal is easier for all who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 "In the extraction of worms generated in the ear, when you care for it with what was said above in division and in the treatment of distillations, and your care does not help; then you should look at the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 "Therefore, if something from worms appears there, then draw it out with forceps or with delicate hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 "But if nothing appears there, then take a probe of this shape, narrow below and wide above; and insert the delicate end into the ear according to the size it can withstand; then suck strongly with it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 "Do the same many times until all worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 "But if they do not obey you to come out, then put the probe of poppy seeds around the ear canal as mentioned above in stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 "But if they do not come out with what was said; then administer the distillations which the ancients have experienced in the treatment of worms; and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let your discharge be oil and medicine into the ear with this tool, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As you see, make it from silver or brass, narrower below, with a small opening below and wider above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Therefore, let the thing that is inside the concavity of the tube be made of brass.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take a rod, and wrap its end with a fitting covering; then pour oil or juice, or whatever medicine you wish into the tube; let it be in the ear; then insert the rod with the covering on top, and press it gently with your hand, until the oil is forced into the concavity of the ear, and the sick person feels it inside; and whatever is poured into the ear, let it already be slightly heated with fire; and beware that what distills into it is not very cold; medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 Chapter on the care of an otitis external.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 When some infants come out of their mother's unperforated wombs.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it happens that otitis externa also occurs in some people from an ulcer or flesh born in the ear.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this otitis externa sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which is not visible; and sometimes it happens near the external opening of the ear canal, which is visible.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, that which occurs deep within the ear and is not visible, is difficult to cure in many ways.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in that which is visible, you must place the sick person's ear on the sun and look into it; then if you see the otitis externa, open it with a small, thin spatula, whose shape is as follows, the tip of which should have a small hollow, part of which should be sharp; and the rest of the spatula should be made of two flat sides: so as not to harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If therefore an ulcer is born from the flesh within the ear, then hold it with a fine hook and cut it out gently but strongly, until all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If therefore the ulcer is deep within the ear, then take a fine, soft probe and heat it slightly; then insert it into the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you find that an ulcer is accompanied by weakness and heaviness of hearing, then try to open it gently; beware lest you injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place linen in the ear according to the size of the opening you made, wrapped in Egyptian ointment; do this for some days until you are assured of healing the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take linen and immerse it in rosewater, grind some white zinc on it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see the ear is beginning to discharge pus, then remove the linen and let it dry with another piece of linen wrapped in a cerotic that has been made with rose oil; let it sit until the hot pus settles; then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If bleeding occurs, then immerse sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear; use the remaining treatment for stopping the bleeding, which is discussed in the treatment of distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 Chapter on the cure of Althaeus (Marsh Mallow) for the eyes.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 Those Althaeus that occur in the eyelids can sometimes be moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore hold them with tweezers or a hook, and cut them out from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place white zinc on the area.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lentil-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And to cauterize them (the wounds) is better after incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For many times they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 Chapter on the care of the eyelids of Græcus (Grandius).
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 Many times something occurs in the eyelids which resembles a growth like Grandius in its strength and hardness, and it is called a Grandio because it is an accumulation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid and the lower one.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 The operation in them (the Grandios) is to examine whether it is a Grandio that appears from the eyelid and moves to all parts, and its matter is easy to remove.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Find then a fissure above it (the Grandio) in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then scrape it from all sides with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it with a hook and cut it off (entirely).
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 But if the removal of it (the Grandio) is not prepared for you, unless after you have pierced the eyelid with a small incision, then it may harm someone weak.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the fissure is large: Then tie it together with stitches: and take care of it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 Unguent restores it (the eyelid) and fills it up.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 If the Grandio is turned downwards towards the inner ear on the surface, then turn the eyelid inside out and hang the Grandio with a hook: besides that you will need an incision, and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 If the eyelid is stretched by an incision, no harm will come to anyone from it.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then wash the eye after snow incision with salted water; and care for the place with it until the sick one heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 On the treatment of Axirnath eyelids.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 Axirnath is a growth that is generated in the upper eyelid's tunics; it mostly occurs in children; and it burdens their eyes, causing cataracts in the morning, and they cannot see the sun's light, because tears flow towards them, therefore, one sees them always lying on their faces, and sleeping on those faces, and their eyelids are constantly moist under eyebrows, which have already been inflated; and Axirnath's protrusion is visible to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of treatment is that the sick one should place his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a linen cloth and prepare in it a piece of linen, and make a circle from it according to the size that contains Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place it on it and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath is gathered in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in the middle of that moisture with a thin spatula making incisions through its length, and let the incision not be larger than the one made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or it is necessary that you find the whole skin until you reach Axirnath, because in many dispositions Axirnath proceeds from the incision according to the shape of a white adipose tissue fragment.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Therefore take it out with the cloth that you have filled between your fingers towards the outside; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it disperses; be careful not to add in the incision so as not to reach the eye with the spatula and hurt it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 If the Axirnath is not apparent to you at the beginning of the wound, you shall easily introduce a little into the wound until the Axirnath appears.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then extract it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the area, and bind it with threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are some people who grind salt, and put it into the hollow of the wound, to dissolve what remains of that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 If a hot abscess occurs in the place, then care for it with soothing plasters until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 Chapter on Ataxmir of the eyes, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft and falls out as it should not.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs grow on the eyelids in addition to the natural hair growth and fall out, then they harm the eye and cause symptoms such as constant tearing, softening of the eyelid, and white film on the eye, until it becomes the cause of eye destruction.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And Ataxmir of the eyes is treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with sharp medicine, as stated in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 The sentence is translated as: "It is treated (by) Ataxmir through incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 By cannulas, according to what I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 It is necessary that you place the head of the sick one on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If therefore it is turned (good), it is well.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if not (turned): introduce the point into it, where there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and let the point pierce through the thread on top, and let this be close to the hairs themselves, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid, in which the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a spatula.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find on the inner part of the eyelid, beneath the added hairs, with the probing spoon from the greater lacrimal sac to the lesser lacrimal sac.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then draw out the thread, and place under the eyelid a small ball of wool from cooked cotton or cloth; then mark on the eyelid with wax, so that it is like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it must be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: since it is varied among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 For there are those who need to be cut from the eyelid of such size, according to the size that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then with the probing spoon find above the two lines you marked, and start from the greater lacrimal sac to the lesser lacrimal sac, and let there be one fissure close to the natural hairs, like the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then scrape it (the fissure) all over.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then connect the two lips with suture, with a needle and fine wool thread: and clean the blood, and let that which exceeds from the threads on the eyebrows adhere, if you wish to make this (the stitching): and if not, do not treat it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then release the suture and the thread for three or four days; afterwards take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, release the wound without suture, and take care of it so that it dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid is to be raised during sealing of the wound and its closure; but it will be better later on.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of healing was taught by the ancients (Ataxmire).
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 Nevertheless, it is a concern for the sick person, and it comes from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And another method is also in Ataxmire: and it is to mark signs on the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then lift the eyelid with three separated or united combs according to the following shape, then cut what is excess with small scissors according to this shape, with equal incisions.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 If it is not possible for you to hold the comb and it does not fit: then take a needle with thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the larger tear duct, and another thread near the smaller tear duct; and gather the threads with equal tension between your fingers.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then lift your hand equally with the eyelid lift; and lift the skin where the wound is marked, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bring together two lips of the wound with a suture; and take care of it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 If a boil occurs at your incision or tear: bind the boil with wax and similar materials from healing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes turn inside the eyelid.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, it is necessary to treat this as we have said in the incision; but the suture is more artificial on both sides.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 On the treatment of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 It is necessary to turn the eyelid and make an incision in the interior fissure, as I have previously explained.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 Then, skillfully make two canes or two thin logs whose length is the same as that of the eyelid and whose width is smaller than that of a spatula; and you have already made an incision at both ends on both sides where the sutures are held.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 Then gather both with finesse onto that which overflows from the eyelid of the eye and tightly bind two canes on both sides using strong binding, and release it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 For the bound skin will die, darken, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If it delays, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 When it has consolidated, lift the eyelid and do not pluck out hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the shape of two canes that you will make according to this form and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 On the lifting of plucked hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	 Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 The operation is to take a fine needle and insert a thread from fine silk gently into it.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 Then gather the ends together, and tie them both with a very fine knot; and let the length of the threads be about one handbreadth.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 Then prepare another fine thread called Alinxotati under it briefly and knot the ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 Then let the sick man place his head in your lap and position it near the sun so that the operation is visible; since the operation is delicate or small.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 Then insert the needle with Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you pull out a natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then pull the needle above the anixotatus: and introduce into the anixotatus that needle; if it is one or two or three, not more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then pull your hand with it until the needle comes out of the anixotatus along with its hair together with the natural hair from the eyelid.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 If the anixotatus is pulled but the hair does not come out with it, pull the anixotatus down towards the lower part, with the thread you have inserted in it, until the anixotatus comes out through the upper opening and is visible to the eye; then pull out the anixotatus and the thread, and remove both of them. Close the eye and let it remain closed for two or three days so that the hair adheres to its place, and new flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is short, then join it with a long hair from the natural hairs and lift it up together; or leave it as it is until it grows out and then pluck it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 Chapter on the care of the xastratum that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this condition occurs in the eye, it is called leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this xastratum is either natural or acquired.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 The acquired xastratum occurs due to the consolidation of a wound, a cut, a cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 The method of treatment is to find this consolidation and to separate its lips, and place a linen cloth between them and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 It is not necessary to use in its treatment things that dry and constrict, for if you do this, the xastratum becomes worse than it was; rather use things that soften, such as fenugreek; and embrocation with water in which althea has been boiled, linseed seed; and an ointment of dyaquilon, which has been melted with some oil; and bathe the cloth with it and treat it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 Thy treasure of care is that thou endeavourest with all thy skill, so that it [the wound] does not become consolidated according to the form which it was first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 This operation that we have mentioned, indeed it is not but a correction of Alzharath, so that the form of the place does not return as it was completely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 Treatment of Alzharath on the lower eyelid, and it is a swelling or contraction upward towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This which is below, is what is truly called Alzharath.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 It is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the accidental one comes from a wound, or a crack, or cautery, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 The method of operation in this is that thou takest a needle with double thread and dost dye it in the flesh and makest it pass from the left tear-duct to the right tear-duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then extend the flesh upwards with a needle and cut it with a broad scalpel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If therefore the form of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, taketh a cautery and place it in the crack, and turn the eyelid with it; and cut two cracks on the inner side of the eyelid, and let them be at the extremities of the two cracks from both angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle: until when they gather together, let their shape be this shape, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then removeth that flesh by its sharp edge which is below, from that which followeth the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then gather together the separated parts: or it with thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them with what I said regarding softening medications and linen, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 If Alxatrati occurs from a fissure, and by suturing, or cautery: then it is necessary to clean the fissure flat under the eyelashes, just as was done before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate the two lips with a linen cloth, as I said before.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 The essence of treating Alxatrati, whether it is above or below, is to perform the operation on it according to how Alxatrati is prepared.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 Indeed, it (Alxatrati) comes in many various forms: and the skillful artisan prepares his craft according to whatever way is possible for him, until he makes its figure return to a natural form, or near to it, and the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 § On the adhesion of the eyelid with conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid adheres to the white part of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore, you must insert the end of the radius beneath the eyelid and lift it up; or extend it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a subtle spatula, which is not sharp like the edge of spatulas, but rather dulled slightly; so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation and the spatula is removed, and does not injure the eye with its sharpness; and your incision should be as if you are peeling off that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the adhesion heals completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Find then salt water for the eye, when cleaning it; or distill into it from distilled water dissolved with zinc.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Fold then between the eyelid and the eye with a linen cloth; place wool soaked in egg white over the eye; and after the third day use zinc and with consolidating substances until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 On the incision of the nail and the protrusion of the skin around the eyes.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is of two kinds.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 It is nerve-like (neruosa) and similar to horn, being soft but strong.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 It is not nerve-like (non neruosa), similar to frozen white moisture, which when touched with iron or tried to pick up with a nail, breaks off and the nail does not sink into it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And neither kind begins except from the greater tear duct, until it slowly reaches the eye, covers the vision, and prevents light and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of operation for its cutting is: that a weak person should put his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open the eyes of the patient and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then grasp the nail with a small hammer and extend it upward.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take the needle and insert it into the nail with a horsehair or cowhair thread, and make sure the thread is strong, slightly bend the tip of the needle, and hammer it in the middle of the nail; pierce it with the needle and tie the nail with the thread and extend it upward; scrape off the side of the nail following the pupil as if you were holding it with hair to its end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.
