Then cut the remaining part at the root of the lacrimal with a thin spatula or with small forceps; and allow the natural flesh of the lacrimal to remain, so that it may not happen that due to the incision there is a continuous flow of tears.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes the nail is extended with a single hook; or with thread, as we said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it is scraped with a soft spatula, whose form is this: (it continues with a diagram)
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And beware that the spatula does not touch the horny layer and there is a break in it, and the pupil is pierced through.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, throw something of crushed salt into the eye or made from seif or zinc and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of it with what is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	 If the nail is not sensitive and you cannot insert a probe into it or a hook cannot be fashioned in it, then this kind of nail is treated many times with medications and heals as I narrated in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	 If you wish to cut it (the cyst), then open the eye of the sick person and take a thin, soft, weak, sharp spatula in this form:
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	 And scrape the nail on top with a razor with subtlety.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	 If you see that it becomes rarefied and crushed and pressed with the razor, then drip from your hour into the eye from seif made from zinc, or from red seif, or ground salt; and cover the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 Then repeat the same operation until the whole thing is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	 Unless a hot abscess appears in your eye; then leave it (the cyst) alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the operation on it with the razor until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	 Prominence of the tear duct if it causes great harm to the eye, should be suspended with a hook and a portion of it excised; not the extremity of the excision, so as to avoid disruption of the flow of tears.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	 Then let blood or make it a purging of the tear duct, or made from zinc, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	 [Section on] Incision according to Alguarid and flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	 There sometimes arises in certain human eyes red flesh composed or laid on top of the pupil until it covers it, approaches it or tightens over the eyelashes and possibly turns the eyelids outwards; resembling a rose-bush balustrade.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the treatment for it is to place the affected person's head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	 Then open his eyes and collect the entire flesh along with appropriate hooks; hold it with a single forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	 Then cut the flesh first, until the whole thing is finished with scissors.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	 And be careful not to hurt the eye during the operation; and make your cut in such a way as we mentioned in the incision of the nail, either with a spatula, which was described in the incision of the nail, or with small forceps, with which the asbestos is collected, according to the form it will take after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	 When your incision is completed and the entire Alguarid is removed, then fill the eye with pulverized salt; or pour in red powder and similar substances from corrosive medicines; place on top of the outer eye a piece of cooked linen cloth with raw egg white to protect it from hot infection.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	 If some Alguarid remains and a hot blood flow persists and you fear a hot abscess; then release the eye and treat the abscess with whatever remedy calms it down.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the operation upon him until he is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	 And similarly do with the added flesh that occurs in the eye of this type.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	 Nevertheless, it is necessary that all weak eyes of natural growth or accidental growth be treated with iron without the introduction of your hand into any of these operations, until you see that the member can endure the operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	 Chapter on the extraction of a seed from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	 The arteries red [ones] that are woven over the eye, and forbid the operation of life: they weaken the eye with the passage of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	 It is necessary for you first to consider if the eye in which the Sebel [artery] is, is strong, and there is no sickness other than Sebel. If so, then gather the Sebel [from that eye].
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And it should be ordered to the weak one, to place his head in your bosom.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	 Then suspend those veins with one or two needles according to your discretion: let the needle be subtle of double thickness, according to this shape, or there may be two needles graduated in one body, according to this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	 Then collect with fine forceps those veins with delicacy, and remove the blood hour by hour until you see those veins being removed from the eye and resolved: take care not to injure the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	 And let your operation be at midday facing the sun, and be very firm in your operation: so that you do not cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	 And when you have finished, then pour into the eye either green or red: so that its own sharpness corrodes what remains of Sebel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	 If it is not possible for you to gather all of that in that hour, then bandage the eye with what alleviates the pain of the eye: and leave it for some days until its pain subsides: and heal it from inflammation with hot poultice: afterwards apply again on top of it according to the same method, until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	 And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	 Chapter on the reduction of Arissatum to the nose.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	 Physicians call Arissatum a fistula, which they treat with cautionery or with sharp medicine burning it, according to what has preceded its narrative.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	 If it does not heal, then there is no skill in that: unless you find upon the abscess at its birthplace and draw out all the moisture that is in it and pus until the bone appears.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	 When the bone appears, and you see corruption or blackness within it, then grind it with an instrument of this shape.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	 And it is called the head-rasp.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	 Make it of iron and let its head be round like a rasp, but pierced with the puncture of a file, or with the subtle puncture of aliskilfer; and place it upon the corrupted bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	 Then turn it around between your fingers, and press your hand slightly, until you know that the corruption has been ground away; and do this frequently.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	 Then restore the place with medicines made from exccentives (dry) styptics.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	 If the place consolidates and flesh grows within it, and the flow of pus ceases; and it remains for forty days without renewing, without becoming an abscess, and no accident occurs in it: then you will know that it is healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	 And if not, then there is no skill in it, except to reduce the fistula to the nostril opening, according to this shape.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	 And it is to expose the bone secondly with iron or with sharp medicine; and when the bone is exposed, then take a gimlet according to this shape, with its end being triangular and iron-tipped; and let the wood of it be a pyramid extended to the end, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	 Then place it upon the bone itself; and let it be close to the tear duct; and extend your hand slightly from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	 Then turn your hand with the gimlet until it penetrates the bone, and you feel it weak; by this means you will find air coming out from it when you hold your hand over its nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	 Therefore, then restore the place with styptic medications, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	 When flesh arises and the place hardens: then the matter that was flowing outward returns to the nose: it is therefore lighter upon the sick one.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	 On the reduction of eyelid prominence.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	 When the eye bulges out completely and no harm or diminution occurs in sight, then it is necessary to loosen the patient; afterwards, bleed him; then place poultices on the neck without incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	 Then place a lining over the eye that is made of acacia, aloe, myrrh, and colophony.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	 Then tighten the eye above with plaster containing many pustules.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	 And the method of pustules is: take soft cloths in abundance and fold all the cloth over four; make many from them; then place one on top of another according to the amount required by the eye; then tighten them over these with a hard cloth strap.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	 And repeat the poultices with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	 Then remove the poultices and release the tightened eye during the day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	 If the bandage becomes soft again, then it is necessary to tighten it a lot; afterwards, remove the bandage after a day and night, as we said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	 If you see that the eye has returned to its original condition, that is good; and if not, repeat the plaster, pustules, straps, and poultices until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	 § On the incision of the bulging eyelid.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	 When there is a rupture in the bulging eyelid, then it protrudes and goes outside the eyelashes as if it were a grain of sand, and disfigures the human form because of this, and the sight wants to cut it; in such a case, the operation is performed according to what I narrate: and it is to insert a needle from the root of the eyelid from below to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	 Then insert another needle with a double thread from the lacrimal side and make it penetrate; then release the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	 Then cut a place for the filum doubli (suture), and tie it with the part of Vua in a circle, and tighten it strongly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	 Then remove the needle, place warm wool on the eyeball in the white of the eye, and leave it until the suture falls with the Vua.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then care for the eye with whatever comforts it until the wound is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	 And sometimes suture the Vua from all sides with a circular bandage until the eye protrudes significantly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	 Then it is pierced with a fine spatula that reaches to the depth of the eye, and the moisture in the white of the eye is drained, and the eye falls down, and enters immediately; then tie it until it is healed.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	 Chapter on the treatment of Alcomant (strabismus).
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	 This ailment called Alcomant is nothing more than pus that accumulates in the eye, similar to descending water, and it is not itself the same as [the fluid] inside the eyeball.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	 And the method of treatment for this is to have the patient sit on a prepared chair or bench.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	 Then take the head with both your hands from two sides and shake it until you see the pus descend to the lower part of the eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	 Then it is figured and does not descend, and the vision is cleared; let the patient see as he saw before; if it does not descend lower, then you know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	 If the descent of the pus is not prepared as we have said, then make the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	 Then take a fine spatula and poke it with it slightly on the horny membrane next to the conjunctiva with the cornea at the edge until pus comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 When the pus comes out, then pour warm water into which you have mixed honey over the eye; or hot water in which you have boiled fenugreek and honey; then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	 On the treatment of water that descends into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	 We have already said the type of water in division and what is suitable for piercing when explaining and demonstrating, then accept the same thing according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then it is necessary for you to make the patient sit with hands on each side of his face facing the light, near the sun; and tie down the healthy eye, and squeeze it very hard; then close the eyelid of that eye with your right hand if the water is in the left eye; or with your left hand if the water is in the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then take your right hand and make a strong pinch if the eye with water is on the left; or use your left hand if it is on the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	 Then place the fingertip near the corona [a part of the eye] on the white part of the lower eyelid; then push with force and you rotate your hand along with it until it penetrates the white part of the eye, and you feel that the finger has reached an empty area.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	 It is necessary that the measurement of the finger's journey to depth be equal to the distance from the pupil to the end of the black part [iris]; and this is called the corona of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	 You will see it [the corona] in the same vision of the pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea layer.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	 Then place your finger at the location where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	 Then press it down once after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	 If the water descends immediately, then the patient sees it immediately on what his vision opens and your finger in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	 Then rest for a while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	 If the water descends, then remove it with another push until it comes out of the eye.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	 When it [the instrument] is driven in and does not go up: then extract almagda easily; and you withdraw your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	 Then dissolve something from clear salt in water: and cleanse the eye with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	 Then place over the whole eye a piece of camphorated wool or flax soaked in rose oil and egg white, and bind the healthy eye with it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	 We, as well as those of our time, place cumin ground with egg white over him [the eye].
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	 If almagda does not obey you in entering the eye due to its hardness, because it is from a person whose eye is very hard: then it is necessary that you receive spathule, which is called Alberid, whose shape is as follows.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	 Therefore, bore only the conjunctiva with it [the Alberid], and not the bottom of your hand into the hole; and there is no other purpose but to make a subtle way for almagda.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	 Then introduce almagda as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	 And for the conclusion of your work, prepare for the sick a bed suitably made, in which he may sleep on his back in a dark house; and keep him away from all movements, and from coughing; and place food for him that softens his nature; and let him not move his head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	 And let the binding be according to its arrangement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	 Then dissolve it [the substance] in that dark house and test his vision; and let him see objects.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	 Then reduce the binding until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	 And it is not necessary to do it during the hour of cure or immediately after cutting; on the contrary, it should be left to others because water rises quickly through a strong wound.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	 If a hot abscess occurs: then it is necessary to open the eye before the seventh day; and correct that with what soothes the abscess, until it is soothed; then without looking at it, and place over its orifice whatever regulates its vision for several days, while it exists in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	 Then gradually exit the house, and convert to your belongings.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	 And know that, in the case of the zaltea, a student is not exempted from watching (the surgery) several times; then he shall dare upon the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	 And indeed a certain one of those from Alayrach has come to us, who said that it was pierced with a perforation in Alayrach, through which water flows.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	 Therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has done that; nor have I read it in any of the old books; and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	 And these are the forms of the species from magda, to stand upon him who is ignorant of them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	 Make them out of copper; and let the ends of them be with this same triangular subtlety, and the end sharp.
Formae magda.	 Forms of magda.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	 Chapter on the care of a born flesh in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	 Sometimes various fleshes are born in the nose, among which there is something that resembles many scorpions' feet; and from it is a cancerous flesh, stone-like, of a dark color; and from it is one that is soft, not of a dark color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	 Therefore, in that which is from these fleshes, soft, not fraudulent, nor cancerous, it is necessary to have the sick one sit opposite the sun with his face towards you, and open his nostrils, and throw a hook into those fleshes; then pull them outwards, and cut what you have taken hold of from them with a thin, sharp spatula until you know that all the flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	 If something remains from the one whose amputation is not possible: then scrape it off with one of the subtle instruments easily, until nothing remains from it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	 If blood dominates you or a hot aposteme occurs: then apply to it what is necessary: or if it is from the malicious apostemas, then hurry to cauterize him until the blood is cut off and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	 Then throw vinegar, or water, or wine into the nose after the incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	 If the nose opens and moisture goes up to the palate, then you know that he is already well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	 If the moisture does not penetrate as it should be, then you know that there is flesh born within the upper bones of the nose, which did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	 Then it is necessary that you insert a thread of linen with some thickness and many knots, and put between each knot a quantity equal to or less than a finger: and let the weak one do it, so he sends out one end of the thread into the nose with a ray, or with whatever he can manage after doing so similar to an awl: and draw out the smell, until it reaches the cavity and comes out on his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	 And indeed often the boys in school do something similar to this Attomus: and it is easy for him who wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	 Then put the two ends of the thread, one which comes out on the nose and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	 Then with a saw the flesh is cut with knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	 Do this until you know that the flesh and the knots of the thread are together.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	 Then extract the thread: and put linen that you have soaked in the Egyptian ointment in the nose after draining the blood for three days or more until the entire ointment remaining from the flesh is consumed.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 Then put a tube made of lead at the end of the matter into the nose, for some days, until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	 If there is need for a cure that will dry it out, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	 To make a purge for the head, when olive oil and other medicines are to be administered through the nose, make it of silver or brass; that it be similar in size to a small lamp, open like a shell; and its passage likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	 And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a tube.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	 And the shell-like instrument to make a purge for the head should be filled and perforated; it should have a handle at its end, with which you hold it, when heating oil in it, or whatever liquid you wish, and fluid substances.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	 And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	 Chapter on the care of the nose.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	 Often a Thelul is born at the end of the nose and it grows and becomes more prominent with days until it becomes an unpleasant sight.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	 And therefore it is necessary to cut it at the beginning of its appearance and to remove all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	 Then place on the spot, either cautery or a burning medicine in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	 If it is slow to be cut and grows, then consider if it is made of hard stone, dark in color, with few senses; then do not touch it with iron; because it is a cancerous ulcer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	 For often I have seen that an apostema was cut open and great evil happened to the one who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	 And if the apostema is soft, not dark in color, and you see that a cut can be made all over it, then evacuate the weak, and cut it without fear, without fear; and care for the place with whatever it may need to dry and constrict until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	 On the suture of the nose, and the lip, and the ear.
Caput XXVI.	 Sint in ore incisa quatuor partes aequales, et sine aliqua differentia: una ab orificio labii inferius ad medium labii superius, secunda a medio labii superius usque ad medium labii inferioris, tertia a medio labii inferioris ad foramen stromae; quarta a foramine stromae usque ad orificium nasi.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 Know that when a solution to continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, it makes little difference for the operation, unless in some humans.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when something happens to anyone from it (the solution), you should consider whether it is a recent wound with its own blood: and then gather together two pieces of the wound with suturing: then care for it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	 And if the lips of the solution are already separated and each part is healthy: then it is necessary to scrape off all the part appearing from the skin, until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then gather together two lips with suturing and sew them up, and sprinkle powder of dragon's blood on top of the blood, and pulverized olibanum: and place above the powders a piece of emplastrum diafinicon, and some other more consolidated plaster: and let it be bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	 Then dissolve it (the solution), and change the medicine: and let it go until the threads fall off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	 The method of suturing is that you gather together the solution to continuity with a needle and thread, as we have said in the suturing of the abdomen: or gather together the solution with a needle and thread, as I told you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	 Chapter on the extraction of neck nodules.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter XXVII.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	 Many people have hard growths like seeds of grass appearing often on the inner lips: and some of them are smaller, and others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	 Therefore it is necessary to turn the lip over, and cut on all sides of the node, and hang it with a hook, and scrape it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then fill the place after cutting with boiled alum, until the blood is cut off.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	 Then, it is to be washed with vinegar, and the place where there is an ulceration should be cleaned with it, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	 On making an incision in the flesh of a newborn on the gums.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	 Multitiimes arises on the gum flesh, which ancients called abscess.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	 Therefore it is necessary that you hang it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root and let pus/blood flow out.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	 Then place upon the wound, powder of oxytocin or other styptic powders, drying agents.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	 If the flesh returns after treatment, and it often does so, then cut it again and cauterize it; for it will not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	 Chapter on tooth extraction with iron.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	 When accumulations form on the surfaces of teeth from both inner and outer parts, and between rough gums, they become decayed, yellowish, and greenish until corruption reaches the gum, and the teeth become foul.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	 Therefore it is necessary that you make the sick man sit between your hands, and put his head in your lap, and grind/file the molars and teeth, where the roughness appears, and remove them as sand-like particles until nothing remains of them; similarly for decayed, greenish, yellowish, citrus, and other conditions until they are cleaned.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	 If the root is removed at the beginning of tooth extraction, that is good; and if not, then perform the extraction again on another day, or second, or third until you have reached your goal in what you desire.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	 And know that teeth require different types of files for various shapes and forms; because the file used to grind the tooth from below is different than the file used between the teeth, according to their shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	 And these files should be prepared by you, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	 On the extraction of tooth pain.
Caput XXX.	 Of the extracting of teeth that have grown into one another.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	 It is necessary that you cure the Tooth from its pain with all your skill, and be slow in its extraction.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	 There is no substitute for it when it is extracted: since it is a lofty substance: until there is no excuse for its extraction, then, when the sick tooth must be extracted, it should be made firm and certified to you by the painful tooth.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	 Often deceives the sick, pain does, and thinks there is worm in the tooth and extracts it; then the pain does not cease until the sick tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	 We have already seen that from the operation of phlebotomists. (This sentence seems to be incomplete or out of context without knowing what "that" refers to in the previous text.)
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	 When the painful tooth is certified to you by itself, then it is necessary that you lance around the tooth with a spatula, where there is something of virtue, until the gums are dissolved from all sides: then move it with your fingers, or with subtle forceps first, gradually, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	 Then place large forceps at that spot, and hold the head of the sick tooth between your knees: which you have already tightly grasped so that it does not move: then pull the tooth in a straight line, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and introduce it under it from all sides with ease, and try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	 If the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary that you fill that hole with a cloth and tie it with the end of a thin radius so as not to break it during your compression on top of it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	 And it is necessary that you do skillfully with the lancing around the gums from all sides much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	 Maintain your strength so as not to break it, and let a part of it remain, and return upon the sick from that wickedness which is greater than his initial pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	 Be careful not to do what ignorant bloodletters do out of haste and the audacity of their extraction, beyond what we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	 For many times they bring about great diseases in men, which are difficult to break and whose roots remain intact or some of them: or they extract it with some jawbones; as we have often testified this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	 Then, after the extraction, it is to be anointed with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	 If there should be bleeding from the places (for it often happens), then rub something of pigs' lard and fill the place with it; and if not, cauterize it, unless you have pigs' lard.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	 The handles of the fine forceps, which move the teeth, should be long at the ends, short at the arms, thick so as not to split when pressed on the tooth; like those of large forceps, until, when you squeeze with them, they do not bite themselves or split: short at the ends, and made from good iron or well-made steel, with pointed ends; and in their ends there should be teeth, some of which enter into others and tighten appropriately by a proper constriction, strong.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	 And sometimes the ends are like the shape of a bird's beak called a ciconia and are strong in compression.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	 Chapter on the removal of teeth and extraction of broken jawbones.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	 When something remains at the site of tooth extraction that breaks, then you should place hot cotton over it for one or two days until the location softens; then insert algasti or forceps, whose ends resemble the beak of a bird called a ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	 This form is forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	 Their ends are made like a chisel inside: or scissors.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not yield with these forceps, then you must be cautious around the root and dissect all the flesh, and insert a tool called Small Plank, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	 The end should be short, somewhat thick: and not dampened so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	 If the root exits through this, it is good: and if not, help with other tools whose forms are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	 The form of the first triangle's end, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	 The form of the subtle triangle's end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	 Also helps with this tool having two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	 And with other tools and instruments which have come before for the teeth's ratio.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	 Also helps with this tool resembling a large hook, whose form is this, triangle's twisted end with some thickness so that it does not break: and do not dampen it.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	 And know that there are many tools for the teeth: and likewise, the remaining tools are not counted, and the wise craftsman, subtle in his art, discovers himself an instrument according to what the operation and illness themselves signify.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	 Because from the illnesses there are some for which the ancient ones did not make an instrument, due to the diversity of their species.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	 If the bone breaks from the jaw, or from other bones of the mouth, or rots: then examine over it in its place with that which suits it from the instruments and forceps I mentioned for root extraction, and help with this gesture, whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	 Let there be some thickness gradually, so that it can be tightened or held with the bone, and it does not flee and move away until the bone exits: and restore the place with appropriate medications for this.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If there is a small rot in the bone, then scrape it away from the rot, and care for it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	 On the locking of protruding teeth over others.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	 When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, an ugly shape arises from it; and this especially happens in women and girls, that is, in those who menstruate.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore, one must reflect upon this.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 For if a tooth has been born after another tooth and does not settle, or its locking or grinding is possible, then pull it out; and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this tool whose shape is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	 It resembles a small beak, and is made of iron pointed at one end.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	 And let your cut be such that you cut it many times on account of the hardness of the tooth and so that another tooth is not disturbed.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	 If it protrudes to be ground down, then grind it with a file made of iron, whose shape is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	 Let it be all of iron, and the handle small with numerous sharp points like a file used to make needles; with which you grind the tooth gradually over many days with ease, so that another tooth is not disturbed, and it falls out; then smooth it and finally scrape it away with certain rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	 If it is a tooth that breaks off and injures the tongue, then it must be ground down until the roughness of the fracture is removed and it is made smooth; and it should not injure the tongue or disrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	 [Section title] On the filing of teeth with gold threads.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	 When the anterior teeth are shaken and knocked by impact or accident, and the sick person cannot hold what he eats to keep it from falling; and you have treated them with medicinal bindings but the treatment did not help; then their condition is such that they should be bound with a gold thread; because silver becomes weak and rots after days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	 And let there be a thread of medium thickness, both delicate and coarse, according to its quantity, which catches between the Teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	 The shape of the rete should be such that you can take a thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth; then weave it with both ends of the thread between moving teeth (either one or more), until you reach the healthy tooth on the opposite side with the needle and thread.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	 Then weave the thread repeatedly to the part from which you started; and tighten your hand with delicacy and wisdom until it is completely removed; and let your constriction be at the roots of the teeth so that it does not slip out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	 Then cut the excess ends of the thread with scissors; bring them together and twist them; hide these under the healthy tooth and the moving tooth so as not to hurt the tongue; then release the thread until it remains tight.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	 If it slips or is cut, tighten it with another thread and it will remain stable for the entire time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	 And this is the form of teeth, and the figure of the rete for two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	 And sometimes a tooth or two return after falling out in their places, and they are retained as we have said, and remain; this does not happen except by the skillful and experienced craftsman.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	 And sometimes a tooth from the bones of the cow is fitted and made like a tooth and placed in its place, where it is reinforced and tightened as we have said; and it remains and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	 Chapter on the incision of the ligament that occurs under the tongue and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	 Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is natural, when a person is born with it, or accidental, from a healed wound.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	 And the operation on it is to open the weak bone in his head in your pocket, and lift up his tongue; then cut that nerve ligament across, until the tongue is released from its retention.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	 If there is something hard and knotted in it, and it is due to the consolidation of the wound; then throw a hook into it and bore through it across, until you reach the ligament, and the knot is loosened.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And beware, lest there be a cleft in the deep flesh, and you cut an artery there, and there be a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	 Then it is rubbed in the incision with rose water, or with vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	 Then place a flannel cloth made of linen under the tongue, which the weak one should hold all night; so that it does not consolidate again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	 If there is a flow of blood, then place some burnt wheat on the spot.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 If blood overpowers you, then cauterize the place with a freckled cautery, which is suitable for that; then take care of it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	 Chapter on the Extraction of the Salivary Gland located under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	 Sometimes there arises under the tongue a boil similar to a small frog, which prevents the tongue from performing its natural function; and it may swell so much that it fills the bone.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	 And the operation on it is to open the weak one's bone before the sun: and examine the boil.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	 If you see it of a dark or black color, hard, in which the weak one does not feel anything; then do not touch it, because it is a cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	 And if it is inclined towards whiteness, in which there is moisture; then throw a hook into it and cut it with a very sharp scalpel, and release it from every side.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	 If blood overcomes you during your operation hour, then place upon it a zegi crushed, until the blood is cut off; afterwards return to your operation until you extract it with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then wash it with vinegar and salt; take care of it with appropriate cure until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	 Chapter on the treatment of a double abscess (boil) in the molar teeth.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	 Occasionally there occur in the throat, that is, glands similar to goiters, which occur outside; and they are called the two molar teeth: when you treat them with what we have said in division, but they do not heal, then consider the following.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	 If it is a hard abscess, of dark color, with few senses; then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	 And if it is of red color and its root is thick; then do not touch it even with iron, fearing bleeding, rather let it be until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	 Then either you will pierce it or it will burst by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	 And if it is white in color, round, and its root is thin; then you should cut it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 And the operation on it is that you consider before the operation if the abscess of it has ceased to be hot and complete rest, or it has decreased somewhat by reduction; then let the patient sit facing the sun, and his head in your lap; and open his mouth, and let a servant be between his hands, and press his tongue downwards with an instrument, whose shape is this.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	 Let it be made of silver or copper, which is thin like a scalpel.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	 When you press his tongue with it and the abscess is revealed to you and falls upon it; then take a hook, and pierce it into the molar tooth, and extract it as far as possible, pulling along with it something from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	 Then cut it with the instrument whose form follows this:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	 They are similar to the forceps, but their extremities should be curved so that each of them has an opening facing directly towards the other's sharp point; therefore, it is advisable to use iron or alfuled that has been soaked.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	 If such an instrument is not present, then cut it with the spatula whose form follows this:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	 It should be sharp on one side but not on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	 And after cutting one almond, cut the other according to this same shape of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	 Then, after the incision, the sick person should rinse his throat with cold water or vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If there is bleeding, he should rinse his throat with water in which have been boiled the bark of pomegranate or myrtle leaves and similar ones from willow, until the bleeding stops; then take care of him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	 And sometimes abscesses other than almonds arise in the throat.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	 Cut them, therefore, according to what I said regarding the incision of two almonds equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	 I myself have treated a woman with an abscess that was born in her throat, which pulled to the side and caused few senses, which had almost closed her throat; she breathed through a narrow nostril, and food and drink had already been prohibited for her, and she had come close to death if she had remained for one or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	 The abscess had risen only so much that it expelled two branches until they came out through the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	 I hurriedly approached and tied one of them with a hook.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	 Then, I pulled it out, and a large part came out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	 Then cut (it) where it can be grasped through the nostril opening.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	 I made that to him which protruded from the other nostril opening.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	 Then I opened his mouth and pressed his tongue; then I attached a hook to the boil; then I cut off a part of it, and it did not run out except for a little blood; therefore the woman's throat was healed, and she immediately began to drink water, then she received food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	 I did not stop cutting from the boil for a long time; and the boil kept coming back in the place where I was cutting, until it grew too large and with her I decided to do something else.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	 I devised another plan, and burned the boil in the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	 Then she stopped adding (the substance); then I went away from her side, and I did not know what God had done with her after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	 [Section title: Incision of a boil in the throat.]
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter XXXVII.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	 When catarrh descends to the throat and a boil forms and is long, it is called a perpendicular; and if it is large and round in the lower part, it is called a balloon.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	 When it is treated with what I said earlier in the division, and the treatment does not help; and you see that the boil has become warm and soft, and thin; then it is necessary to cut (it).
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	 And if the part that is collected is round and not long, and it is red or dark or black, and there is no sensation; then it is necessary to make an incision in it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	 For fear of harming the weak (person).
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	 Therefore when you see it as I have said according to its whiteness and length, make the weak person sit facing the sun; then press his tongue with the instrument whose description has preceded; then attach a hook to the throat and pull it downwards; then cut (it) with one of the two instruments that I mentioned in the incision of the two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	 It is necessary that you do not cut from it, unless what is added beyond the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	 If you cut from it more, you harm the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then after cutting (incision), use what we have said about the incision of two amygdalas and take care of it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	 But if the sick person is afraid of cutting: then it is necessary that you use your skill in cauterizing it without fear and trembling.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 The method of cauterization in it is not, except with sharp water: and it is to put the head of the sick person on your breast.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	 Then press his tongue with the instrument which we have said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	 Then take from the water which I have told you in the chapter on cauterization, and make a ladle not extinct with it, and place it not thick nor thin, but of a medium thickness, and fill the depression of this instrument with it, whose shape is as follows.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	 Let the end of it where the medicine is placed be concave like the concavity of a cochlea (spiral shell-like structure).
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	 Place the instrument with the medicine on the boil itself: and let the sick person lie on his side so that saliva runs out of his mouth from the internal medicine, so that something does not fall out of it into his throat and harm him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	 Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	 And you apply it to the boil for a quarter of an hour with the quantity of the half-hour until you see it already softened and calmed by the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	 And if you want to take the purge (cotum), and roll it up on the end of a rod, and pour the purge with the medicine, and insert the rod with the purge into the cannula from above until the purge adheres to the boil.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	 Repeat this frequently until you achieve what you desire concerning cauterization of the vein.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	 Then release it; for it will dry up and fall off in three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	 If you require to reapply medicine, reapply it; and after cauterization cleanse the vein with a cloth moistened in butter, and cleanse it with that which is around it from the medicine; and rub it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	 Externally it shall be treated with plasters, internally with poultices, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	 Therefore, this method of treatment is healthier than surgery and more distant from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	 And sometimes the vein is treated with something more subtle than cauterization and cutting; it is treated by fumigation in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	 Take calaminthe, hyssop, origanum, rue, asafetida, chamomile, and wormwood, and similar herbs; mix them all together, or some of these in a pot, and immerse them with vinegar, and boil them; let the pot be coated with lime; and have a hole in the middle of the pot, over which you place an instrument concave in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	 Make it of silver or copper; insert the end with a grain into the mouth of the sick person, until the vapor reaches the vein through the pipe, until the vein is filled with smoke.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then repeat over it frequently, until it dries up.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 And beware, do not perform this treatment at the onset of the abscess.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 Usually a pus forms in an abscess, and it is not appropriate to do this unless at the decline of the heat of the abscess.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 If this instrument is not available to you, then take a pipe, and at the end of it prepare an oxhide layer; so that the bone of the sick person is not burned, because the oxhide prevents the vapor from burning the bone; and this is good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 On the extraction of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	 In this text, it appears that we are discussing Chapter XXXVIII which deals with the extraction of thorns and bones from the throat.
