Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	 And abrade it and clean it as well as you can according to whatever position it presents to you and with whatever tool is available to you: when it does not cause you harm by the vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	 And know that the instruments for cutting and sawing these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their thickness, their subtlety, their size, their smallness, their hardness, and their scarcity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to prepare every kind of instrument suitable for the operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	 And know that these operations signify to you the type of instrument you need, when your study requires it for a long time.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	and the knowledge of the modes of this art, is evidence of the modes of diseases: for then indeed you will find what suits it from yourself, concerning all afflictions with instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	 And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments, which you shall place examples on what you cut, and proof on others.
Forma Serrae.	 Form of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	 Form of another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another Saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	 This form of the Saw should be well made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Let the upper part of its arc be made, and its edge from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and let it be pyramidal.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 Form of the Razor for Joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 The head of this rasp should be shaped like the head of a star-shaped nail: and its points should be shaped according to the form of pointed file nails.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 It does not suit it unless that it rubs against the heads of joints when they are broken, or a large and thick bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 Form of a larger Razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	 Form of the middle Razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 Form of the wide Razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 Form of a rasp with a hollow.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 Form of another fine Razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 Form of another Razor with a curved end.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 Form of the small fine rasp.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 Form of the rasp for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also, form of a large rasp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 It resembles a saw and its end is like a rasp: it is used in many places for the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 The form of a rasp that suits for cutting it which has been pierced by bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its end is triangular and sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, it is necessary that everything we have said be made from files, cutters, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 Section on the incision of extremities, and the setting of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Head LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Rotten ends, either from external cause, or internal.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 When you have been treated for that corruption with medicines and the treatment does not work and you see that the corruption is spreading into a limb which has no reaction: then it is necessary to amputate that limb until the spread of corruption stops, so that the weak part can go out through it either from death or from the greater malignancy which is due to the loss of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 The mark that happens to it is what decays the limb, until it seems burned by fire, or rots after blackness: until that rot reaches the following limb and creeps through the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Approach therefore with the incision of that, and likewise if the cause of corruption is from the strike of certain venomous creatures such as marine scorpions, weasels, nettles, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If therefore the corruption, or strike is at the end of a finger, then incise the finger, and do not leave any space for the rot, so that it may reach the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly if it happens in the hand, then incise it from the root of the palm and do not leave any space for the rot, until it reaches the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades that, then incise the arm near the elbow at its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If however the rot passes through and you see him about an elbow, then it is the death of a weak man.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And beyond that in cure, is the amount of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly do with the foot when rot invades a finger, then cut it at one knuckle: and if it reaches the bone of the toe, then cut the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 If however it rises to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If however rot has reached above the knee, then there is no remedy for it, but to release and abandon the weak to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the manner of cutting a limb, or of binding it is, to tighten the ligament at the lower part that you wish to cut and to tighten another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And extend one of the ligaments downwards, and extend another ligament upwards towards the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 Separate the flesh that is between two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then, it should be cut or tied.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth on all parts, and not touch the healthy place with the knife; and an injury added to the weak should happen, and the abscess warm.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 If there is an internal bleeding during the operation, then quickly cauterize the place; or put some powder that absorbs blood on top of it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your medication until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happened to a man in his foot, this same thing happens as I told you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 This is because there is blackening in his foot, with a burn resembling fire burning; and the corruption first happens in his toe, until it began to affect his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore, the man moved himself away from it, after he saw corruption happening in his limb with great pain, which he found out through pain and burning; and he cut it off at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long period of time, the same corruption happened to him in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 Therefore he came to me, and I tried to recover that loss by placing some medicine on his hand after cleaning his body; but the loss was not recovered, and it began to affect another finger; until corruption began in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 He then called me to cut off his hand; but I did not want that, hoping for the recovery of the loss from me; and I also feared death for him at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 The virtue of a man was above his misfortune.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 After he had given up hope in me, he returned to his own land; and reached me concerning that matter, because he hastened, and fell on his whole hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 I bring this narrative only as help for that which falls under the genus of this disease; and it is a signification to be understood, and according to which it should be done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 Chapter on the cure of sinuses, and the quality of cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	 Chapter XC (Roman numerals).
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess extends until it collects pus; then it breaks or perforates, and what is in it exits through the pus, and leaves a vacant place as if it were a vessel; and the skin that is on top of it has become thin like a piece of cloth which has been woven fine; and it does not progress to complete corruption nor press into bone, nerve or ligament: it should be called a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula; however, if its space extends until corruption presses into one of these members, then it is called a Fistula or ulcer.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And its treatment is to incise the entire skin as it rolls; and especially when it has become thin, and made like a piece of cloth; and trust that it will not adhere because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 If you hope that the skin will adhere, and this final corruption does not follow as a result; and if there is thickness in the skin from the flesh, then treat it with clisterium: and consider for a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 If it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor; then clisterize it with medicine from Egypt, which is vinegar, oil, and zinziber; parts receiving equal amounts should be combined in a vessel: and boil it over fire, until the medicine turns red: and let it become thick like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take that which is necessary for you: and dissolve it with water and honey, and enema it with the mixture; and sew up its opening, and leave the medicine within for two hours quantity.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then extract it with expression: do so for days until the sinus is purified and the stench removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And when an enema with ashes of water is to be administered, if this medicine is not present at hand: and it is that you receive the ashes from vinewood or from hollywood; and cast upon her the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then cook it and give an enema with it until you are confident that the sinus is purified.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient is not able to bear the Egyptian medicine or water and ashes, then give an enema with water and honey, which has already been mixed with something from crushed onions.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or give an enema with honey and wine mixed, for the property of honey is to purify and cleanse; and wine makes the sinus adhere, particularly when there is excess dryness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you have done that several times and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has been removed: then give an enema with it which produces flesh within it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And it is that you receive dyafinicon from the plaster; and dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine; or give an enema with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the opening of the sinus is narrow and it does not accept an enema cannula: then expand it slightly with iron; or place linen wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or basilicon ointment within it until it expands.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And likewise, if there is also a large opening, then gather its lips with suture; and leave within it an amount for the enema to enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if there is an opening from which pus flows, it should be elevated towards the higher parts; then cut it at a lower location within itself, so that the pus can run out towards the lower parts; because when the pus is obstructed in depth, it prevents flesh from forming in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus approximately below it as you wish; then try to prepare the member with a preparation by which the pus can flow out easily according to what you are preparing yourself.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try not to retain anything from the pus at all; and receive consolidating medications that are placed on the sign, appropriate for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 And spread them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the cloth be of such size that it allows communication of the entire Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors directly into the opening of the Sinus a hole larger than the opening of the Sinus itself.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread a layer of soft ointments on another cloth according to the size of the hole; and place it above it at a distance from the opening of the Sinus so as to facilitate the exit of the pus; do not remove the large cloth unless after several days, once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 The one who is above the opening of the Sinus, that is the one you should remove at any hour to let out what has accumulated in it from the pus; and so that you know whether what runs out from it is much or little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And again consider the location of the Sinus itself, whether it feels pain to its master or not, and whether there is a boil in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When therefore your treatment is thus extended and you see the matter which comes out of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus already adheres or approaches to adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 If for a long time a subtle virus comes out of the Sinus, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are some people who heal slowly in their wounds, and there are others who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 If for many days an undigested pus comes out of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If therefore the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its treatment prolonged: then add drying medicines in the process, but let the physicians do so that the medicines be in their substance humid and in their virtue dry, such as dyafinicon ointment when excess is added to it from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the last remedy to be used, it is that you take dyafinicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and stir it over it old wine equal in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then make a mixture of these ingredients and use the remedy.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And make a similar remedy to this, when you do not have dyafinicon ointment at hand, honey, when you boil it until it thickens, and use the resulting mixture.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or take myrrh, aloes, and frankincense; grind all of them together and powder it over honey while it is above the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then cover it with a cloth and press it on the Sinus: and cover it with honey that you have boiled until thickened, powder over it and place it on the cloth, and press it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And at times aristacularia longa (long caltrop), roots of the celestial lily, and the lily are administered; and wheat flour, and chicory.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use these simple remedies, or compound them, grind them and sift the powders; and powder over honey as I have said, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the ailment in the sinuses persists and is not cured by this treatment, you should know that there is corruption deep within it; or it has already made an impression on the bones, or other hard parts of the body, or ligaments; then treat it with fistula treatment, as previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 Chapter on the treatment of warts and the worn nails, and incisions and amputations.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter CXCI (111).
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Warts are boils that appear under the nail of the thumb or big toe; perhaps they may also grow on other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When the wart persists and is neglected and treated with boiling water, it may rot away and emit pus until it erodes the root of the nail; perhaps it rots completely and the corruption reaches the bone, so that there is a foul smell and the tip of the finger becomes wide and turns black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you treat the wart as I have said, and your treatment does not help; then it is necessary to cut off the entire overgrowth that remains from the nail with a knife.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 Indeed, cautery is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If the bone is healthy and the nail is also sound, and there are no additional overgrowths on the nail; but the flesh has become compressed beneath the nail and begins to hurt and wound it; then place a fine radium under the angle of the nail which wounds the flesh, and push it upwards; and cut the flesh easily with a knife, and apply medicines for burning, corrosive substances on what remains of the flesh until it is completely removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If pus already presses into the bone, then it is necessary to make an incision in that bone and extract it; for a bone does not heal while there remains pus-filled bone.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see pus and decay advancing towards the finger, then cut it off at a joint, according to the previously mentioned reminder of this procedure.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 If there is a nail injury or blow and a violent pain occurs, then it is necessary to use leeches first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail off with a sharp Spatumil, from below towards the surface.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And ensure that the incision does not reach the skin beneath the nail, for you will cause a violent pain to arise above it, and this will be the cause of the growth of new flesh at that location.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then treat the place with something that alleviates the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 The finger that is born in some human hands may be entirely fleshy; and it may have bones in some of them, and a nail in others; and it may be born at the root of the joint or its growth may occur in some of the joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 Therefore, a finger that is born at some joints does not move; and one that is born at the joint of the finger may possibly move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 The one who has flesh, therefore, can be easily cut.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 Therefore, make an incision at the root with a broad Spatumil.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 The treatment of one whose growth is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from making an incision on it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 In the finger that is born at the end joint, then it is necessary to make a round incision in the flesh until the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then cut the bone with a saw that fits among those fitting to it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 Consolidation, however, which often occurs in fingers, happens either by birth, that is, it is born with it, or from consolidation of a wound, or from burns, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, one should remove that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place between them linen or gauze soaked in rose oil to prevent consolidation or separation of the fingers; or place between them a thin lead plate until the area heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if there is consolidation on some fingers with the palm, then remove that consolidation as appropriate and in accordance with the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 [Section title: On the vice of incision.]
Caput XCII.	 Chapter XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Ulcers are veins twisted, thick, filled with melancholic excesses that occur in many parts of the body; and their most frequent outlet is in the legs, especially in the legs of travelers and laborers, and those carrying heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, it is necessary to administer the expulsion of the body from black cholera at times by means of a strong purge.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then let the patient's vein be opened in the basilic (vein).
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The treatment of these is with iron, according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One method is, to cauterize and draw out black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And the other method is, that the vein is raised and all (the blood) is drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The section of this (vein) is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Anoint the leg with warm embrocation and much water until the thick, filthy blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the sick person's leg from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the thigh with bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein at one, or two, or three places with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then raise (the vein), i.e., draw out the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and it is necessary that a leech be applied to the sick person first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the fingernail down as far as necessary: until a sufficient amount of blood is expelled, and as much as the strength of the sick person can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Then tie it up: and order him to abstain from foods that cause black cholera; and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and this is harmful for the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Raising (the vein) is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Shave the leg of the sick person if there are many hairs.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then insert it into the bath or apply embrocation on his leg with warm water until it turns red and veins swell; or exercise it by strong movement if there is no bath available, until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then dry the skin along the vein's incision lengthwise; or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then peel off the skin with combs and scrape the vein from every side until it becomes visible to touch; and at its appearance, you will see it turn from red to blackish purple.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When the vessel has been reached through the skin, you see it as white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert the Ray under it until it raises and comes out of the skin; hang it with a blunt comb.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then make another incision near that one with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then peel off the skin from above the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then lift it with Rays as you did before, and hang it with another comb as you did at the beginning.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then make another incision or multiple incisions if necessary for that one.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then peel off and cut the last incision at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then draw it out to the incision above that one.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 And do this until you draw it out from the incision above that one or all the higher incisions, until it comes out completely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If it does not obey you to be drawn out and lifted; then insert a sharp awl with a strong thread and tie it and draw it out itself; or insert the Ray under it and turn your hand over every part until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful not to cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it becomes very difficult for you to lift it out and an injury may enter the patient from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you have extracted [it] completely, then place wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or olive oil, on the wound site, and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If it is a wound from a vine with twisting and spiraling, not straight as we have said, then you should open it completely along all its twists and the places of the spiral.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then hang it with hooks until you have extracted it entirely; beware not to cut the vein or wound while making the incision, for it will be difficult for you to extract or remove it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Therefore, exercise caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The shape of the incision for healing a wound from a vine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The shape of the blind hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Its not like the other hooks with sharp tips that might cut a vein; rather it is thick and curved but not too pointed. If it were delicate, it would pierce the vein through its delicacy; on the contrary, it should have unnecessary thickness as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 On the extraction of the leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, as Alizegi and the Arabs say, and in dry, hot lands with little softness, that is, where no plant or tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 Its generation is indeed from putrefaction that occurs beneath the skin, as it does within the bodies of snakes and worms called ascaris, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of its incision is that it occurs when there is a very hot inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then let the location be bled.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal, the vein begins to come out from that bled location.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When its end appears, then it is necessary that you wind a piece of lead around it, whose weight should be one keil of a drachma, up to two drachms and knots; and let go the suspended lead from the arm.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out of it towards the outside, wind it with lead and knot it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it extends a lot, then cut off its part, and wind the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut off its root before it has come out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Because if you cut it, it contracts and goes into the flesh; it causes an abscess to occur, and pus in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore it is necessary that it be treated gently and drawn out gradually until it comes out from the end of it, and nothing remains in the body from it; and from this vein, in some people, something comes out that is five fingers long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has reached me, for a man of twenty palms has come out from it.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If it is cut during your treatment: then insert a probe into its opening and pierce it with a long hole, together with the body, until all that is in it from the matter is evacuated; and apply a poultice to the place with medicines for some days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat it with treatment for abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 This vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or on the foot itself; and many openings occur to it, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore treat it as we said earlier, and with what was mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 On the section made over worms generated beneath the skin, and it is called Bouina's illness.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter CXIIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This illness is named among us Bouina's disease because it frequently happens to cows and there is a small worm born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it moves throughout the body, ascending and descending; and it is detected by the sense when walking from limb to limb until it bursts at any point where it bursts on the skin surface and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 And its generation is from the corruption of certain fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 As worms and snakes, that is to say, leeches and roundworms occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And it is feared due to its malignancy.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it moves within the body and rises to the head and reaches the location; then possibly it opens there and comes out and destroys an eye; and this happens frequently.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 When it is desired to cure him and extract the worm itself; then this cannot be done except during its walking and the appearance of the worm to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you compress what is above it and what is below it with a strong binding.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut through it and extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it is probed into the flesh and the worm cannot be found; then place a cautery over the location with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And the greater one that is feared, is its corruption which destroys the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If you see it has already reached the head near the eye; then compress above it with a good tightening band.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut through it and extract him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 And the sick person should use self-cleaning of his body, with remedies that dissolve corrupt fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let them avoid foods causing putrefaction to themselves.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 On incision for the illness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter CXV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This illness is called Nakir on our land: it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs, then changes from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself have already seen it, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 She rolled up her arm, and I saw a swelling smaller than the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after staying for one hour, I saw a swelling crawl with a worm-like motion, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than possible: it was like liquid silver flowing from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 The pain therefore has receded from that place, and it was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then it stayed for one hour, and ran through the rest of the body, until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that he was turning all over his body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 I was therefore amazed at the speed of his change from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed, before that, I had not seen this sickness with my eyes in such a manner as it was now.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 Nevertheless, I saw many who found pain change from one limb to another; and I did not see it as I saw it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that it was anything other than because the woman was from those who are driers of bodies, detached veins; whence it appears that the windiness (ventosity) was changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and moist bodies, hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Therefore, when you desire to cure it and the patient feels that pain; then if it appears to you as we have said, then press on top of it quickly and below it; and cut above it until the windiness compressed is expelled; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 But if you do not see it with your eyes: then cure it with the expulsion of the body, and with that which expels the windiness, and crushes them with stinking pills, and pills of mastic, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 Chapter on Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are diversified according to their kind, and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 The diversity of them is because there are some that have large points and small; concave and blunt.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among them are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And among them are those which have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among them are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 Those indeed which are among the limbs, fall according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 For indeed the limbs are hollow from principal members, such as the brain, and heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, bladder, and similar things.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When therefore it falls among any of these limbs and the signs of death appear to you, which I will tell you afterwards, then it is necessary that you turn to the extraction of this arrow, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these signs are not evident to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then draw it out yourself and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 Among the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and pierces the bone and comes out from above the brain is: because strong seizures, fainting, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, confusion of intellect, and vomiting of cholera can occur.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps blood comes out from the nostrils, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And from the wound place whiteness similar to plaster comes out.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And it comes out like a boil-like tissue from there.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and pull out the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of an arrow when it falls in the heart are: that it is close to the left breast and feels as if it is fixed in a hard place, not in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps there is an arrow movement similar to heartbeat: and blood runs out from the wound black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And it follows that coldness of limbs, cold sweat, and fainting occurs.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, you should know for sure that death is approaching.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 The sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is that sputum comes out from the wound, and the containers following the neck should be removed, and the person's complexion becomes weak.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And it breathes out a large, deep breath and seeks cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the chest, which is in the lung: then it is close to small ribs: and a great panting occurs with very strong pain, with sighing, and all the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls into the abdomen and sticks there, something like feces comes out from the wound, or pus, or a broken intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore, there is no hope for treatment of this person or for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out: and something proceeds to the outside, and the pain is greater than the illness: then you know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, like the face, neck, throat, spatula, assistant, dorsal spine, crossbar, thigh, and similar members are saved according to several arrangements when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I saw about these arrows to indicate by that for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 That is, because a man fell with an arrow into his tear duct of the eye, at the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 So I extracted it from the other side, under his ear fat: and he was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Jew which had fallen upon him under his lower eyelid, and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not find any part of it except a small portion that adhered to the wood: and the arrow was a large one from Turkish arrows with a soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore, the Jew was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 The arrow was Arabic, and it had ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 I cut it then across the two wings: and it was already sunken into his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I sharpened myself with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I extracted another arrow from a man who fell upon it on his abdomen: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed over him and nothing changed in his condition, I cut across the arrow: and I sharpened myself upon it, and extracted it: and he was cured, and no harm came to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man whose arrow fell upon his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman whose arrow fell into her womb, and the wound was healed over it; and the arrow remained within her, and no change occurred in her disposition or any harm to the woman from her own natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 And I saw another man whose arrow fell upon his face; and the wound healed over it, and remained, causing him little pain; and many such things happened.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 And I extracted an arrow from a man of the king's princes who had it fall upon his nose in the middle, and already it had turned slightly to the right; and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 I was therefore called for his treatment until three days after the loss of the arrow.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I found then a tightly closed wound of the arrow.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 Therefore I asked it with fine probing, and it did not feel it; but he himself found pain and a puncture on his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore I hoped that this was the wound from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I applied then the place with a plaster containing attracting and digestive properties, confident that the wound would open up and reveal the sign of the arrow so that I might cut it; but this did not happen at the place where something happened, indicating that the arrow had missed the spot.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I remained then with the plaster on him for many days; but nothing happened at the place; and the wound healed over in the meantime, and he remained weak from extraction of it until one day he felt the arrow in his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I therefore laid an acidic medicine on the wound for many days until it was open; and when I tested it, I felt a subtle arrowhead tip which stuck to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added into the wound opening that sharp medicine until we could see clearly the arrow tip; and it passed by me with a space of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Then, when the wound was swollen, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey to come out; then I did not stop trying, and devising means over it with various methods, until I began on a certain day with well-made forceps, according to the shape that comes in the end of the chapter, until I pulled it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed physicians judge that the cartilage of the nose cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore healed it, and the wound became firm and was healed with complete health; it did not harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you the quality of the extraction of some arrows; put this rule and meaning on what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Because the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended with a narration; nor does the book include it, and the skillful craftsman compares little to much; and with what is present, to what is absent; and he discovers a new operation, and a new instrument for descents of foreign things in this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I therefore say that arrows do not come out from the members on which they are fixed, unless in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by attraction from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which goes out where it entered, is either an arrow passing through flesh and is drawn out, or it is a foreign body inserted into a cavity, such as a splinter or stone, that cannot be extracted.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not come out within the hour that it fell: then it is necessary to let it be for some days until the flesh surrounding it rots; and its attraction will decrease, and it will come out.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly, if it impales a bone and does not come out for you, then let it be also for some days; and press and move it every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not come out from you after days, then it is necessary to bore around the arrow in the bone from all sides with a fine drill, until the arrow enlarges.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already penetrated one of the ventricles of the brain and some symptoms are observed that I have mentioned: then refrain from pulling the arrow and let it be until its course becomes even after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if the arrow has reached the heart, death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed, except in the body of a bone only, and does not penetrate to the heart; and it remains sick for some days, and nothing of those symptoms occurs to him: then apply your skill in drawing out the arrow.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If it is firmly fixed and does not obey you to be drawn out: then administer a drill around the arrow as I have told you; then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow is already concealed in a part of the body, and hidden and concealed from sensation: then search for it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel it (the wound), then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for drawing it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot pull it out because of the constriction of the wound and because the arrow is deep, and there is no bone, nerve or vein there: then pierce it and let the wound swell up until it can be pulled out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If there are ears attached to it (the arrow), then free the fixed flesh from them on all sides as much as you can, with every skill you have, and the skills, if it cannot be pulled out by force of the flesh in breaking or twisting the ears, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And when you draw out the arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hand with forceps in all directions until it comes out: and carefully and skillfully, so that the arrow does not break, and its drawing and extraction become difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot pull it out within an hour, then leave it for a few days until what is around it begins to rot.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then return to it: for the wound will heal itself. But if blood flow opposes you, then administer what I said in the chapter on cure: and keep your skill away from cutting a vein, nerve or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And apply all your skills in every way possible to draw out the arrow: and let it be done with ease, calmness, slowness or firmness, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 It is necessary that when pulling out the arrow, it becomes weak in the shape it was at the time of the arrow wound.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more helpful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible according to the shapes (of the arrow).
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 Arrow that emerges from the opposite part of another, already proceeds to something exterior: or makes a hump at the tip of the arrow by sensation from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it protruding: therefore cut above it, and let the section be according to the quantity so that forceps can grasp it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw it out; for indeed, it becomes easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrow presses into the bone and swells itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: leave it for several days; then repeat drawing it out until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If there is wood in the arrow, then push it along with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If the wood has fallen out, and you wish to apply pressure: then insert a concave instrument into it so that it enters the concavity of the arrow's tip; then push it along with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the arrow is concave, then push it along with the inserted instrument.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 The arrow is held by that (thing).
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut away all the concave flesh where the poison is; if you can do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then care for it with whatever suits it (the remedy).
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow falls into the chest, or stomach, or bladder, or side: and is near that which you touch with your fingers, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut above it, and take care not to cut a vein or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then heal the wound, if you see one, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 Extremities are similar to the beak of a bird, which have been made like iron: when they seize upon an arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 They become numerous, large, small and medium, according to the size of the arrow, its smallness, and the width and narrowness of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The shape of the projectile is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 The shape of the projectile is dull.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is a dull extremity like a radius so that it may be guided into the concave arrow and propelled with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The concavity of the projectile-extremity is concave like a bird's feather: so that it may be guided into the arrow and propelled by it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 The veins to be bled, whose course is accustomed in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 Among them, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called two Herbs; and two arteries, appearing in the two temples; and two veins that are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two Gudgi veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 These are the veins that are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 However, the veins to be bled in arms, there are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is Cephalic, and it is from the forest side; and the people call it vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And Black.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilica, and a branch of the Cephalic; and the people call it vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And Basilica, and it is located on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicar.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the people call it vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the cord of the arm, and it is placed on the elbow; and this is where it is bled, and this is the one that appears above the thumb in a visible manner.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And Savaliar: and it is the vein which is between the ankle and malleolus; and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
