Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is which is under the nail curvature from the forest side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And second is the Saphenous: and its place is near the heel on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And vein of the ankle: and its place is near the heel from the forest side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And on the other leg there are three similar veins.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 Section on bloodletting of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 Indeed, bloodletting of two veins which are after the ears is beneficial for old catarrhs, and hemorrhoids, and old sores of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of bloodletting is as I have mentioned.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 It should be shaved that the head of the sick person; and it should be rubbed on the place of two veins with a rough cloth rubbing well.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the sick person should bind his neck with a bandage until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 The places [of these] are behind the ears in two depressed locations on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore, seek them with your finger and when you feel their pulse under your finger, mark that spot with hot wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take a lancet-shaped phlebotomy instrument, and it is called "Incisor".
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it [the incisor] beneath the vein into the skin until the phlebotomy instrument reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then lift up your hand with the vein and skin to the top, and cut the vein along with the skin incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two fingers joined together, or about that much: and allow as much blood to come out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then tie it up with thread, and let it heal.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now the incision of them [the veins] and their cauterization has come to an end in the beginning of this book.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Chapter on phlebotomy of two arteries in time (of illness).
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The phlebotomy of the two arteries which are in two times [of illness], is useful for ancient migraine: and for sodom, prauvam, obtalmia assidua, and for the course of superfluidities effused acutely to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of phlebotomy [of the arteries] is as I have told you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 Let the sick person tighten his neck much, until two veins appear to the senses by a clear manifestation: and their pulse should be demonstrated under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then mark them with hot wax.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then lift up the skin over the vein to the top with your finger as an index and insert the phlebotomy instrument from below, and lift the vein to the top.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And cut it [the vein] as you did with the two other veins: and allow as much blood to come out according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then loosen the constriction of the patient, and place your finger on the hour vein.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then put on top of it [the wound] and the fingers, and bind it tightly from above with a strong constriction; and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now let us leave the memory of them [veins], and their cutting, and their extraction; at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 Chapter on the vein of the forehead after the vein of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 But the remedy for the vein of the forehead is after the vein of the head, for old diseases of the face, and for migraines, and redness; and for fetid ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of its [the vein's] bloodletting is as I told you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 The patient constricts his neck with a ligature until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the tool called Fossorium [Lancet].
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form [Description of lancet's shape].
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the sharp point that is on the head of the Fossorium [lancet] on the vein, and strike it with a mallet or another tool in the same manner; and let the blood flow according to the amount you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then loosen the perforation of the patient, and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it is opened with a wide bloodletting tool [Leech].
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, it is not necessary that the bloodletter be of sharp tip, as the other bloodletters, but rather wide-tipped.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And the bloodletting is to be performed across [the vein] because the bone is close by; and perhaps the bloodletter will break it when it is sharp.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 Chapter on Bloodletting of the Veins in the Two Tear Ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 But the remedy for the two veins that are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes is for the eye with scabs and redness; and swelling in the eye, and diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 And the quality of venesection [phlebotomy] is that it tightens the sick man's neck with a ligature.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then, for the venesection [phlebotomy], you shall be standing above his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 And the venesection [phlebotomy] shall be made transversely, slightly longer than usual, with a small incision, narrowly, because there is no flesh at that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If the venesectioner [phlebotomist] is subtle in his point, perhaps he may break it.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then, let blood run as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 Put a bowl over them [the incisions], and tighten them at night, and untie them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 Chapter on the venesection of Nasal Veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The venesection of the nasal veins is for acute fever, severe headache, facial ailments such as hemigraine and redness that occurs on the face, especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 The quality of phlebotomy in this case is to tighten the diseased neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a sharp and long phlebotomy needle; and fix it in the middle of the leper's nose, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Since the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And it is necessary that you should hold your hand with the phlebotomy needle a little; and let blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie [the leper's nose] up at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 For it heals quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 Chapter on the phlebotomy of veins (Guidegu).
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 Guidegu's phlebotomy has two advantages: it helps in constriction of cough and onset of leprosy, melancholic diseases, impetigo and bad ulcers, and those that consume, i.e., herpes or eomenias.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 The quality of the phlebotomy for them is to tighten the diseased one under each neck with a bandage; and let the craftsman stand above the sick person's head, and the sick person be seated on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then the phlebotomy needle is slightly longer than usual for the vein phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then draw out a measured amount of blood or as much as you see is necessary for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Then loosen the bandage, and tighten two veins with a constriction in the middle; so that the sick person does not faint.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And let [the sick person] go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 A wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 Chapter on the phlebotomy of veins (Algeberich).
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 Algeberich's vein phlebotomy has the advantage that it contributes to the alcohol in the mouth, and corruption of the gums; bad ulcers; cracks in the lips, and bad ulcers, even those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 And the quality of phlebotomy is that you should make the sick person sit before you; and tighten his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then roll back his lip, and look at the two veins; one is on the right side of his lip, and the second on his left; and the demonstration of each is through their blackening (or darkening).
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And that is true: because around them there are small veins, black ones.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Cut (or make an incision) therefore in both places with a cutting instrument.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If there is doubt over you and you do not know which one it is (the vein): then pay attention to the larger incision and make a more obvious one.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And similarly, do the same with the two veins that are on the upper lip; and most commonly it is done in this way; and cut the two veins which are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 [Heading or Title:] Phlebotomy of the Vein under the Tongue after the Phlebotomy of the Head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 But the advantage of phlebotomy for the veins under the tongue is that phlebotomy of the head (or cephalic phlebotomy) is for affections in the throat and diseases of the neck and mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that the sick person should sit between your hands before the sun; and open his mouth, and look under the tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for a vein; and the color of each declines to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Cut (or make an incision) therefore both (veins); and be careful not to damage your hand while phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 For there are arteries under it (the tongue), and perhaps blood will flow from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 [Heading or Title:] Three Veins on the Arm.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are to be cut for bleeding are found in which, and the practice of bleeding from these veins is common in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And the cutting of them (the three veins) is performed in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Or by piercing it with a wide-mouthed lancet (myrtinus): or by oiling to soften the edge of a decline: or by cutting with a small knife (cultellus), and this is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 Thus, Alnesil is what is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from these (the three veins) there are wide and narrow forms according to the width of the veins and their constriction. The form of the lancet (myrtinus) should be wide, as you can see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And it is suitable for opening hollow veins, full, extending, appearing, thick ones and those that contain coarse, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 And this lancet (phlebotomus) is of lesser width and sharper at the tip.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 And it is suitable for the bleeding of fine veins that contain thin yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 [Section title] On Bascilica Bleeding.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 The Bascilica (one of the three veins) is beneficial for bleeding.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it draws blood from illnesses that are located under the throat and neck, since it follows the chest and abdomen, and it is suitable for the lancet (phlebotomator) to be cautious when bleeding this one, because beneath it there is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If therefore the lancet (phlebotomus) makes a mistake and adds in the puncture, it will cut the artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore, the lancet (phlebotomus) must not puncture it: instead, it should be cutting with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the Basilica does not appear by clear manifestation, then it is necessary to remove it and move to another or seek one of its branches; or to use a ligature on the arm in its place.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 For indeed it is clear and when you cut it with a lancet as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you wish to perform a phlebotomy on it, then it is necessary before the ligature of the arm, that you touch the place until you know the pulsating spot.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the spot with hot iron, afterwards cut the vein with a concave lancet as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And beware that the blow does not fall into the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you see that, while you tighten the ligature, swelling in the place which you marked with hot iron, then that swelling is the swelling of an artery; therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood rise at the phlebotomy, like the urine of a boy, and it is subtle, red; then know that it is from an artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Then hurry, and place your finger on it in a long space, afterwards remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then tighten the arm and release it; and let the weak avoid moving it; and beware of fearing it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not move it for several days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 If the blood does not flow off and binds you; and if medicine is not present to you at the moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its ends contract and the blood flows off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig tree, and grind it; take one half portion, and tie it over the place of the vein's constriction with a ligament and piles until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	If it is cut off (the blood), it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 If not: then the care of him with that to whom it preceded is remembered at a place removing blood flow: and removal of blood from him is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the smallness of the wound location, and the possibility of binding from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of the Vein Fusca.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The assistance of the vein Fusca for phlebotomy is that it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body, because it is composed of a branch of the Basilica, and a branch of the Cephalica, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 And it agrees with the phlebotomist that she (the vein) is above the fear of phlebotomy, for under her is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 If therefore it adds (in the phlebotomy) in a puncture and finds a nerve, stupor occurs in it, and the healing of it becomes difficult, and perhaps it is not healed completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If it is concealed in certain men and is subtle, and does not show itself: then one must place the phlebotomy of you with which you will phlebotomize it, section with Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If the vein is between two nerves, then pierce the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 Chapter on the Vein Cephalica.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The assistance of phlebotomy of the Vein Cephalica is that it draws blood from the head and contributes to eye troubles.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And in this vein it is necessary to use olive oil or myrtle oil if you wish (to phlebotomize), because it is safer than all the veins since it is neither an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 It is fitting for you during venesection (phlebotomy), that you ask the barber only to cut the arm, and seek a more lenient spot: it does not harm him if no such place is found on first striking, but he should return to the same spot with venesection several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 Perhaps a boil occurs in some people when not venesection is performed on first striking, but it does not harm him the boil in any case.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Chapter on the utility of venesection (phlebotomy) and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The qualities and accidents of venesection (phlebotomy), and the correction of which you should consider.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 Firstly, you should know that venesection (phlebotomy) is not administered except in the conservation of health and its persistence, and with caution against the approach of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And that venesection (phlebotomy) should be performed on one of the three veins that are at the elbow, namely the Cephalic, the Radial and the Median Cubital vein.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And that venesection (phlebotomy) should be performed at the beginning of spring after fasting, in summer and autumn and winter after food intake, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 And that venesection (phlebotomy) should be performed on the first or third day after passing three hours since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 However, venesection (phlebotomy) administered for illnesses does not have a fixed hour: but when it is appropriate and necessary for that purpose, it may be done at night or day, and in every hour, and in every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 And it is not fitting to venesection children until they have reached fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 And women in childbirth should not be venesected from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Seniors are not to be bled who have passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 If anyone wishes to be bled for any reason: it is necessary that they clean their intestines before the bleeding with a soft enema, if there is much retained feces in them; so that no putrid waste from the intestines may attract during the bleeding harmful substances to the main limbs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 The patient suffering from gluttony (toctina), that is, satiety and nausea, should not be bled; nor the drunkard, nor the one who has just come out of drunkenness, until that state has been removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 The sick person with dropsy should not be bled.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 Care should be taken not to bleed again after a colon accident, or vomiting, or diarrhea, or increase in sexual activity, or labor, or exercise, or sleeplessness, or fasting, and all that dissolves the power of the body or an animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then, consider with subtlety the humors before that, if the blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medications; if it can be done for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Then enter a bath, if there is nothing to prevent it; or exercise in some way, so that the blood may be made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And place the bleeding of him in the chest on the third day, as we have said; and try to have his chest evacuated by all bad animal accidents that day: such as anxiety, anger, fear; and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, punishment, excess, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And he shall have present the things with which customary use of man is accustomed from aromatics, fragrances, perfumes and similar things in quantity according to possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the phlebotomist sit on a stool higher than the phlebotomy stool; afterwards he shall draw out his arm and rub it with his hand twice or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then tie the ligature with a linen strip and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the ligature be moderated, because an uneven ligature, either by excessive tightening or by loosening, then it prevents the flow of blood; or in softening, then even it prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after ligating, it is necessary that the person being bled rubs his hands together simultaneously until the veins swell and become apparent to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then the phlebotomist cleans the place of bleeding with a little oil, traditionally.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then he places his index finger of the left hand on that vein at the place where he wishes to make a cut, slightly; so that the vein is not driven away and the blow is cushioned.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Because the veins are as thin and elusive as strings at the place of bleeding; and from them is that which is full of wind, and when you put the lancet on it, it contracts under the lancet, and it deceives the lancet-wielder, and he does not open the vein; and if he opens it, it is constricted; for this reason therefore, the lancet-wielder should be firm and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Then lay aside the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If, then, one vein is opened, that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then do it again with the other vein at that place slightly or above it quickly; if not there.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 And if he faints or is weak, then dismiss him for a day or two; and do not tie the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps a hot abscess attracts (it).
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the wound is small and the blood flows thinly, fear that the required amount of blood will not come out: then perform another phlebotomy in the same vein according to correct procedure, and add a little more in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And perform it quickly before the abscess is removed, for in many people an abscess site is dangerous during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If therefore you see the abscess itself, then do not repeat (the procedure) over it at all, for it does not excuse anything on your part.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 Place something made of oil on top of it, because it promotes the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 It is better in this place than olive oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 And similarly administer oil ointment in every phlebotomy of yours where you phlebotomize the veins against the flow of blood: and they do this with Tyrian alfrache and sagzenea when it is placed on the site.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 Blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If a large abscess occurs at the site of phlebotomy, which often happens especially for those who are not used to phlebotomy or where there is a small wound in the vein, then hurry and place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated slightly, on the site, and keep it on for an hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 It is necessary that you do this after the blood leaves from the vein itself when it has finished, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something remains in the site after several days that is black or green, it does not harm it: and if you wish, place on top of it some aloe, myrrh dissolved, or something from the juice of mint, that is, camphor or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 And indeed often occur abscesses and swellings at the venepuncture site in the Basilica (Church).
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Place your hand upon it (the swelling), then if you find a soft spot beneath your pressure, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Be careful, so that you place something on it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 For perhaps blood of the artery may flow out from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But make an ointment for it with the substance containing styptic (a substance that stops bleeding), so that the place hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 It is necessary that you draw out blood from every person according to the quantity of its virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears as a color spreading on top of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it flow out until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 It is necessary for the one who is full, strong and requires bloodletting, that it be done once, to increase the venepuncture of the vein, and that the bloodletter be on the side; and for the weak one, it should be the opposite.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 It is necessary that it be drawn from the veins and that the opening be narrow; and better that which is administered in venepuncture, that it be a cross-section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 This method of bloodletting is safe from bleeding and from cutting a nerve; and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than bloodletting by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 And to the one who often faints upon venepuncture, it is necessary that before bloodletting he eat a little bread soaked in water of mulled honey; or if he is warm, let him drink cool water; and draw blood from three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 If it is of cold constitution, then let it take bread soaked in honey-syrup or in scented honey-syrup with spices, or in fragrant aromatic syrup, before phlebotomy.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If it occurs that syncope happens during phlebotomy and the cause of this is excessive bleeding, then it is necessary that one drinks meat water and subtle aromatic syrup, and uses aromatics with alum and linens his chest with it, and uses the rest which we said in the division on syncope through evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 He who wishes to dislocate his arm and release blood through the second method: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is for great evacuation and whose strength is weak, that he releases blood gradually by the amount of its strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 But he who wishes to dislocate his arm and release blood through the second method, and his body is strong: then let him do this after seven or nine hours following his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 He who wishes to draw blood from his body towards the opposite side of which it inclines: it is necessary that this be done on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 In a body where much blood is already heated and sharpened and causes a fever: it is necessary that the blood comes out once and a large quantity is extracted from him; the opening is enlarged until syncope occurs; after which you should observe all conditions of phlebotomy; and you should place your hand on his pulse during the flow of blood, so that death does not occur in place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 For it often happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and falls due to neglect.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 It is not appropriate when you wish to cut the arm, and to let out blood when the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of the blood becomes difficult, that you press strongly upon it and the bruised area is quickly extended.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 This is bad indeed, rather let it be, until it is bled again with the lancet.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 Either remove with the sharpness of the lancet that which has coagulated from the blood in the opening of the vein, and place something dissolved in water over it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 Place something made of turpentine (tyriaca alfaroch) or sage (sagzenea), and place it gently on it until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 But if the vein is already tied off (apostemata), then let it be and do not cover it up until the tumor subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 If there is a need to let out blood by piercing again and no excuse for it, then either lance the same spot or pierce another vein on the other arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The ligament of the arm is lanced where Fusca and Basilica are located, and they cannot be found because they are composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 And the quality of lancing (phlebotomy) is that an unhealthy person should immerse his hand into hot water until it turns red, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then it should be tied with a cord of moderate tightness on top of it.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then the lance should be pierced across slightly, not widthwise or lengthwise; and the opening should be wide, and your lancing should be at a joint of the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the flow of blood is forbidden, then immerse your hand in hot water and let the blood flow into the water until you fulfill your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 If, however, you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from the repetition of hands in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 Much more is the course of blood in hot water during winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 And this vein's phlebotomy is safer than all the others, since it is not a pulsating vein and there is no nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 However, phlebotomy of the little finger on the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is that you should tie the thumb with a ligature or your hand after you insert it into hot water, until the vein is inflamed and shown very clearly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then, make an incision across it (the inflamed vein).
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 Keep it (the instrument) so that you do not lose your hand with the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 For under it (the incision) there are exposed nerves of the fingers.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then dip your hand again in hot water and let the blood flow out in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not repeat it (the procedure) in hot water, the blood coagulates in the vein's opening and prevents its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 Therefore, when you extract the necessary amount of blood, then place oil and salt on the vein to prevent it from clotting quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, it is necessary that you do this with every constricted branch (of veins).
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 However, the benefit of this phlebotomy from the left hand is that it is beneficial for spleen diseases; and do the same in its phlebotomy as you did in the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 The benefit of the saphenous vein phlebotomy is for diseases in the lower part of the body, such as uterine diseases, menstrual retention, kidney weaknesses, and old sores of hips and legs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of phlebotomy is such that the unwell person should immerse his foot in warm water; and he should make friction over it until the veins swell; and tie above the joint of the foot with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 The vein location is at the heel, appearing towards the thumb; and it branches out from there into many veins on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 So, phlebotomy should be performed in a larger vein branch or at the heel in its accumulation; because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 If phlebotomy is performed on the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves which are under it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 Place your phlebotomy instrument across [the vein], as if you want to cut it; and the phlebotomist should be named Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 If the exit of blood is forbidden, then immerse his foot in warm water; and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the phlebotomist misses a vein during the first attempt, then he should move the phlebotomy upwards a little; because it is safer and you need not fear harm from it, as long as you are careful around the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The location of the Sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel from the forest side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 The aid for this phlebotomy is for pain in the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 The quality of this phlebotomy is that the unwell person should enter the bath and hurry; and tie his leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel with a thin, long bandage, without it being apparent except for that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears, then perform the venesection according to whatever skill is possible for you, either by transverse or longitudinal manner: and it is better, or as if you cut it with an incision, or sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 Its position is safer, and it is very much hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the senses: then perform venesection on one of its branches, and that which appears on the back of the foot and turned towards the auricle: and avoid the nerves, and let the quantity of blood flow as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then dissolve the constriction, and place skin over the venesection site, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 It heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 On Ventosection, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	 Chapter XCVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 They are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 And Venosection is done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 With scratching and bloodletting; and the other is venosection without scratching.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 And this Venosection which is without scratching, is done in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	 Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 And the venosections that are administered with scratching and bloodletting are fourteen in number on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 One is Ventosection of Alnocrates, and it is the last of the head; Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; ventosections of Alhagdahim, and they are two plates of the neck from both sides simultaneously; ventosections of the brain, and it is under the mandible on the lower jaw; ventosections of two spoon-like areas; ventosection of Alachosos over the end of the tail; ventosections of two faucets, and they are in the middle of two arms; ventosections of two legs; ventosections of two ankles.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 And Ventosatio does not draw blood from you from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and therefore its virtue does not fall out of them, as is the case with that accident from phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 It is not necessary to administer ventosatio, whether with fire or without it, in any disease that occurs due to congestion, until the whole body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 If necessity requires ventosation due to disease or custom, we administer it at the beginning, at the end, and in the middle of any month, and at any time whatsoever.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 Because there are some people who, when their blood multiplies, until it requires the extraction of it by ventosation, find in their head a heaviness and swelling.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	 And among them are those who find congestion and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And among them are those who find itching in their face, forehead, and darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And among them is one who scratches the place of his ventosation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And among them are those whose laughter is increased.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And among them are those who find the taste of blood in their mouth: or their tongue is pushed out, and the blood is spat out.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And among them are those whose sleep is increased.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And among them are those who see in their sleep blood and redness, and the dead, and wounds, and similar things.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When we see something from these, especially if it is during the middle of the third month: then we order ventosation to be done, after two or three hours have passed since that day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 The advantage of ventosation for the neck is that it relieves heaviness in the head, and what is discharged goes to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 It is necessary for it to be afterwards, after evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And this, indeed, is a ventosus in place of cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 And it is not allowed to use that one who has cold constitution or where there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 For it does great harm to him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 And because of that, it is not necessary to use that in old people and where there is cold illness of the head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 Whoever becomes accustomed to it, generates oblivion upon him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 And because of that, you must warn the ventosator to put his hand down when performing ventosus for a moment, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 Ventosation or Alkehel, is in place of phlebotomy Fusca, phlebotomy Basilica and because of that it causes coughing, constriction of breath, breathing of the instrument's crack, coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 And it is necessary to push ventosation Alkehel for a moment, because if it is placed lower, it generates weakness of the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 Ventosation alhagdahim causes accidents of pain in the head, migraine, hemigraine, perforation, and pain in the roots of teeth; and is in place of phlebotomy Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And you must warn the ventosator not to press his hand during scarification, so as not to cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 Ventosation under the chin causes alcohol in the mouth, corruption of gums and similar illnesses that are in the mouth; and it is instead of phlebotomy aleierich which are on the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 Ventosation of spatula causes alchafacham, which is caused by bending and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 Internal cauterization of two hot irons provides assistance to phlebotomy of three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalica; because it draws blood from all those small veins which are in the flesh; and those small veins draw from other larger veins until the attraction reaches three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 And it is necessary that you instruct the cauterizer not to proceed too much in scraping; because the place is exposed to flesh and there are nerves and arteries beneath it.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 And a Ventosa that evacuates (cauterizes) on anuses provides assistance to hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 And it is necessary that you instruct the cauterizer that the Ventosa should be large and of iron; because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps small Ventosas may break; and it should be scraped with a deep scraping.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 The cauterizations of the legs diminish by a clear reduction; because they draw blood from the entire body, and provide ancient pains in the kidneys, womb, and bladder; they induce menstruation, and provide gout and dropsy; and they are in place of phlebotomy of two saphena veins and alhorcoben.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 Nevertheless, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 And the aid of a Ventosa for alhorcoben is close to the aid of Ventosas for the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The quality of the positioning of Ventosas is that you place the Ventosa first in a vacant area and suck with moderate suction; and do not prolong the positioning of the Ventosas, but place them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place at equal intervals; and do not stop repeating this and continuing, until you see the place already redden and swell, and the redness appears as blood; then scrape, and repeat suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider in the arrangement (or disposition) of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For one who is of tender flesh and rare pores, it is necessary to incise (him) once, not more; so that the place does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And order the Wind-blower (the person using a bellows) to enlarge the incision and not to penetrate too deeply; and moderate the suction in ease, speed, and gentle movement.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is a thickening in blood, then it is necessary to incise (him) twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 In the first (incision), the way is opened for subtle bleeding and its moisture; and in the second (incision) it is scrutinized for the extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	 But if the blood is very foul, then let there be an incision in the third (time); so that it may follow the last (procedure).
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And for the ultimate (purpose), when we wish to draw out blood slowly or slightly, it is sufficient for us with one incision.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to extract much blood, let there be multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure that the blood is thick; then it is necessary to incise deeply; and the end equal in the incision, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 [Paragraph] What that should be administered from the oils for the position of the Bellows-blower, and what the Bellows-blower should beware of.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 In one whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and the pores of it are narrow, the Bellows-blower should be anointed with oils that are opening, soothing, resolving; if it is in the summer (time), as oil of aloe, or oil of walnut, or oil of sweet almonds, or oil of pumpkin seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is in the winter (time), then use oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomile, or mustard; and similar to these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 If there is excessive fat, cold: then use oil of amoracchia, or oil from balsam, or white oil, or oil of anise; and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 If there is much wind in the large pores of the flesh: then it must be forbidden from oil, and it must be washed those places of wind (after wounding) with rose water, or cold water, or sea water, or cucumber water, or portulaca water; and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 He whose blood is of much moisture, wash (the wound) with vinegar, or with water of myrtle and sumac; and similar ones.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 He whose exudations are excessive and thick, wash (the wound) with old wine, or with juniper water, or decoction of anise, or chamomile; and similar ones.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 It must be avoided that wounding in a bath or in the foot of the bath; rather it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour or two.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 And it is not allowed for anyone to sleep after wounding.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 Chapter: What must be done to regulate the wind or the lancer before wounding.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 And afterwards, it must be considered firstly: if the wind or the lancer is choleric and its sharpness and inflammation prevail over the blood; then it must receive cooling agents, such as grape molasses; also a paste with vinegar and lettuce, radish, juniper, and yarrow; and similar ones.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 And place his food with chickpeas, cooked sheep meat, and preserved foods with vinegar; and similar ones.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 And if his complexion is cold, let him drink syrup made from honey or almond, or yarrow decoction made from seeds; and let him drink moderately aged wine that is between old and new; and it is prescribed that he should eat sparingly.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 Place his food with the chickens, and let it hatch; and sparrows, that is, small birds; and doves' chicks should be sprinkled upon it.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 It is necessary that the drink on the day of ventilation and phlebotomy should be more than the food; it is necessary to give something in the drink for some people in hours of tyriaca alfaroch, or medicine from musk, that is, muscata, or aleselithe before ventilation; and before or after: so that the main limbs may be strengthened, and the blood may become more subtle.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 And it is not necessary to take it in a heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 Chapter on ventilation without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 Ventosations that are without scarification are those placed on the liver, spleen, foot, and on the abdomen, umbilicus, places of kidneys, and on the groin; because these members do not bear scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 And it is not sought through them, unless by attraction of blood from one member to another; as we place ventilation on the breasts in sickness of flow of blood in the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 And we use them to dispel cold and unpleasant wind from one member into another; as we place ventilation on the abdomen and umbilicus.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For it rarifies the member, warms it up, and removes pain, because it dissipates that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 It is also placed on the kidneys when it happens to them obstruction, or stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 By its virtue perhaps it opens obstruction, or extracts the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 And similarly when placed on the liver and spleen for bruising in them in both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 These ventosations are administered empty, excepting only with incision.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And at times they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And at times they are filled with warm water in cases of pleurisy: and this is for the purpose of inflating the ventosa (bladder), and it should be large, hot water alone, or water in which herbs that agree have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 Form of the ventosa administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 Its width should be two fingers open, as we have made it; and its depth should be half a palm; and on its side there should be a small hole in the middle of its length, according to the size that the needle can enter: it should be made of brass or citrine, with rounded edges, equal ones, cleaned: so as not to injure the body in its position above it; and in the middle of it, a bar transverse from brass or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now this ventosa is made large, larger than we have described, but not much smaller than that, according to the severity and age of the one who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 For the ventosa for children, and for those exhausted (faint), are different from the ventosa for men and large-bodied people.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	 The quality of placing this ventosa on the body with fire over it is to light a linen cloth or a small candle from wax; and place it on the middle transverse bar that is in the middle of the ventosa: so that the fire is lit below the lower part of the ventosa, so that the weak body is not burned.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	 Then place it on the body: let the finger be over the hole that I have said, until we hold the ventosa; when we need to, remove the finger, and steam will come out of the hole, and the ventosa will immediately open.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	 Then light a linen cloth according to its way, and repeat it if necessary.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	 In Ventosa that is administered for the sickness of pleurisy with water, there is no transverse rod nor hole: it is not administered unless because it is filled with water and placed only on a limb.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And the size of the Ventosa, insofar as it is larger to hold much water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 Chapter on Suspension (of Sanguisugum).
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter CXIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Sanguisuge are not administered in many places except where the position of veins is not possible, due to their small size, such as lips, gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 In a body part devoid of flesh, such as fingers, nose, and similar areas.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 And the quality of their use is: to use venom from leeches that are in sweet clean water, free from decay.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then they should be released day and night in sweet water until they are hungry and there remains nothing in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 Afterwards, the body is bled first with phlebotomy, and then with cupping.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then cleanse the sick part until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 Then place them on top of it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are full and fall off and there is a possibility of sucking the wound with cupping, then it is more advantageous to help: and if not, cleanse the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then with much water, rub and press.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.
