If the flow of blood persists after the removal of leeches and it needs to be stopped: then immerse a linen cloth in cold water and place it on top until the bleeding stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If there is an increase in blood, then sprinkle powdered alum or gall nuts or similar substances from poppy seeds on it until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or place half-peeled beans on the area and let them remain until the beans stick to the area; as the blood stops flowing.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And it is necessary that if the application of leeches is repeated, they should be changed when possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 If leeches are forbidden from suspension, then cleanse the area with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or fix a needle in the areas until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then they are placed, for they themselves feel something from the blood, and immediately adhere to it.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you wish that they should fall, sprinkle some powder from ground aloes, or salt, or ashes upon them; and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 Parts Seconda End. (This is a notation for the end of the second part.)
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Parts Thirda of the Surgical Book of Albucasis.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Universal Discourse on the Repair, Dislocation and Healing of Twisting, and Similar Matters.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also often necessary in the art of medicine and it is a repair of broken bones and dislocations of joints in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know ye, O sons, that fools among doctors and the common people boast about this chapter; and those who have never seen the book of the ancients, nor read a single letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And because of this reason, this method is scarce among the learned in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never found any good in it; nor have I acquired that knowledge from it except for the length of reading ancient books and diligence in understanding them until I extracted the knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I have attached myself to experience and diligence throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 Now I have described for you from that in this chapter everything that contains my knowledge; and beyond what my experience has passed over, after I abridged it for you, and freed it from the occupation of prolongation, and abridged it with the end of abridgement, and showed its end with a descent; and I have formed many forms of instruments used in it, since it is by adding to declination, as I did in two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and Collection of Fractures of Bones, from which a preliminary is necessary before we begin the remembrance of broken limbs and various ones, if any one in particular.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary, as I shall say in the preface of this Chapter, that the main points and sections, to which the understanding of the craftsman must first be directed concerning their truth: namely, that you and those quick to learn know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say therefore, that when a fracture, dislocation, twist or accident happens to someone, it is necessary then, first of all, to phlebotomize him and dissolve it, or both at the same time: unless something forbids it, such as weakness of virtue; or he who is affected by one of these things is a boy, an old man decrepit, or it is a time of violent heat or violent cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, beans and hare; and let wine, thick meats and filling foods be prohibited, and let the belly not be filled with them or any food that fills veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until you are secure from a warm purge and do not fear the emission of matter to the limb; then let the sick person return first to his own regimen, with which his custom has been accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary for the sick person to eat nutritious foods in abundance, thick, heavy, containing viscosity; such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, heads and feet of cattle, entrails of sheep, eggs, fresh fish, and thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 With this regimen, the setting of the fracture is done more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones in men who are old and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be held together and consolidated according to their own nature always, due to the drying out of their members; and they are consolidated and joined in the end of softness, like the bones of small boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue around the broken bone from every side, which has a thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they are united, and bound together until it reaches the end of its strength and firmness, just as it was in the beginning, until it does not prevent anything from its operations: and for this reason, it is necessary that you place nourishment for the weak, in which there are heaviness, viscosity, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know, that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of the limbs: since a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the bone of the head: and a fracture of the bone of the chest is different from a fracture of the bone of the back: and similarly all other limbs are diverse one from another: and I come with the reminder of every type of fracture exposed in its chapter distinct from the others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 And the types of bone fractures are also divided within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since it happens that the fracture is bowed, apart from the fact that stars occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture is made according to the length of the bone: and these are the fractures called stars, that is, small star-like pieces, or additions extending, like in a reed when it is prepared with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not extending: and there is the fracture with wound and separation in the head: and there is a small crack-like fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every type has its own skill or tool for restoration, according to how the memory of it will come, separated in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from this it is known that the bone fracture is twisted and its protuberance: and its appearance to the sense and sound when you compress it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When there is no apparent tortuosity in the location, nor does striking the bone with movement produce sound for you, nor does a weak person experience great pain: then there is no fracture there; rather, it is possible that there may be tortuosity or a small fissure. Therefore, it is not necessary to move it with your hand and compression at all; instead, place something from the medicines whose memory comes to mind on top of it for a while until the appropriate time arrives: then tighten the dressing with subtle pressure.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And you should know that when a location arches and is split into two, but except for the occurrence of satagiae, all parts are removed from their original position; then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour for its correction, applying pressure on it before a hot abscess occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If however, there arises a hot abscess, then let it be for several days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then apply pressure on it according to whatever means possible from lenity and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And you should know that the restoration of it, and its setting, is easier than the bone in which satagiae occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tighten it according to whatever memory comes to mind of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are satagiae in the bone, then it is necessary for extension of this broken member from both sides, if the hand is available or the foot; or with your hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And your position when placing the member over the place should be equal according to its natural shape until the parts of the broken member extend; then attempt to return those additions with all skill and in whatever way you can in their places: but be careful according to your strength, that pain or injury does not occur to the weak from your operation; and attempt according to your strength to apply one bone of the two with its companion, according to the best shapes.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary at that hour, that you probe and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and make it even with the measure of your force.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of a violent extension, and a strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For often, through their operation, they make an abscess hot, or a contraction in the limb; as we have already seen this frequently happen from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then bind after it has been made even, and a proper operation, and a tightening of that limb; and peace, and calmness; and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And make him take care not to move it during his watchful hours, and sleep, at the time of its revolution, and his agitations, and during fasting, and all his movements with the last of his strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And to avoid a position of the limb that follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 That is because when he feels pain or injury in the position of a limb, then it must be moved to another position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And beware that the position of his is even and straight; to avoid twisting in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of the tightening of a broken limb is as I have said.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that broken limbs are classified according to their smallness, size, and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those which are small, such as the arm, finger, foot, and similar, then it must be a wrapping of soft, fine cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 Those which are large, such as the thigh and leg, it must be a wide, hard wrapping.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because the broad ligament connects a large member and tightens it from all sides equally, so that no spot enters into it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then begin, after your evacuation, to place the suitable poultice on it, on soft wool over the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wind the ligament over the site of the fracture with three or four layers, according to how deserving the member is; and tighten your hand slightly with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go with it to the upper part above the site of the fracture and tighten less than your previous tension, which you had applied on the fractured site.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then withdraw with the bandage from the site of the fracture slightly, and soften the tension gradually, until you take out a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then receive another plaster, and wind it again over the fractured site with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Then go with the bandage to the lower part below the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your operation be in the tension of the bandage and the softening of it, according to what we said in the upper bandaging.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the bandages, from soft wool or cloth, which fits the curvature of the fracture if there is any curvature; and if not, you do not put anything on it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then wind over another plaster.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place stars evenly on top of these bandages, immediately if there is no swelling or hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or an abscess in it: then place on it what removes that abscess, and remove the swelling; and let it be for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then tighten the stars on top of it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 And let the stars be from the middle sections of a wide reed, shaved and shaped wisely; or let them be made of wood from which cribra are made, which are made from pine, yew, that is, palm branches, or calingi; and let the size of every star be according to this shape and the same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 Nevertheless, it is necessary that the Astal (clamp) placed on the tract be slightly larger and broader than the others: and the length of the Astal should be according to what is allowed by the size and smallness of the member.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then tie over the clamps with another lint, according to the first tying.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind above with threads properly, according to what we said about the tying: and it is, that your binding on the site of the fracture should be more: and as much as it is farther from the fracture, the binding should be less.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 Because if the threads are thick, as I saw in the operation of foolish ones placing their threads from twisted flax ropes, there is a great mistake: because the binding falls with them outside of quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And very fine threads again do not suit: because you will not gain by the binding with them what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 And it is not necessary that there be less than a finger's breadth between one clamp and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the sick person is injured by the ends of the clamps after the binding at healthy places: then put under them from soft wool or camel's wool until nothing is injured from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with wound and disruption occurs in the skin, I shall come with the discussion of it in the second chapter according to its peculiarity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken member should be bound with clamps from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 Because when the member is large, it is not necessary to place clamps on top of it unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the occurrence of a hot ulcer.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 And this is the method of plasters, which were used by the ancients, which are placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 Common method of emplastrum abbreviated, restoring a fracture, suitable for various temperaments, particularly women and children: because it is from that which heat does not prevail, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And is, as you receive from the flour mill, and it is the kernel of the grain that hangs on the walls of the mill near the motion of the grinder; and prepare it thus, except that sieve it with egg white; and place its mixture not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of emplastrum, restoring a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Take almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath; squeeze them all with a quantity of myrrh equal to 10, and aloes from both equal to 5, and alethil 20 times; grind all of them, sift them, and mix them with water of alethil; or with egg white if the temperament of the patient is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this emplastrum.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, it restores broken bones quickly, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of emplastrum, which also benefits a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Take mugath, mess, white altea, all of them with a quantity of myrrh equal to 10, and aloes from both equal to 5; Armenian pine nuts 6 times; grind all of them thoroughly, sift them, and prepare with water, or egg white; administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of emplastrum for joints and bones separated from their places; it relieves the pain that occurs to them, and cuts (cure) a broken bone.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take cooked wool, immerse it in vinegar, and boil it in oil; place it on the location.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And in this plaster there is no power of restoration, but it is good for the sedation of a hot abscess; and it drives pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Method of the plaster that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take leaves of the deaf fig and leaves of the wild parsley; grind all of them, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Method of the quick-healing plaster for use in the restoration of a bone fracture; and whenever you wish to soften the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Take equal parts of the root of althea, chamomile, violets and dried herb flour; grind them all together and make a paste with wine if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated, then make that paste with coriander water or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method for softening a hard abscess when there is a restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take equal parts of the root of althea, flax seeds, balustium, lentils, vetch, samsucca, violets and chamomile; grind them all together and make a paste with willow water or sweet water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply it according to the heat of the member and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 But Hippocrates did not say in his book that it should be placed on a fractured member during its restoration unless it is made of wax and oil; nothing else; and he said that it should be between coarseness and finesse.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus, however, thought that resins should be placed on a fractured member during its restoration, in which there is an evaporation of heat, such as myrrh and aloes and frankincense and similar things from those we mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of Plastering for Wound and Pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Make paste with chickpeas, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, althea, and equal parts of salt. Grind them well and sieve it, then prepare plaster from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 But the amount required so that there remains binding, then it is to be dissolved, is such that you consider if no pain occurs, nor itching, nor is the bone displaced from its place: then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If itching or pain or swelling occurs at the site: then hurry and dissolve it at that hour itself, remove the plaster from it; and take a soft cloth or sea sponge, wet it with warm water; and wash the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain is soothed.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on top of it a piece of thin wool, soaked in vinegar and oil or rose oil; and bind it over it for the night until you are sure of removing the heat from the wound, and the swelling of the limb subsides, and the pain is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the process for a fine binding and small plaster; do not bind it tightly with your own binding or with thin ones until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all the conditions have been completely removed; if you need plaster and binding, then repeat it as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing happens to the limb from what we said, then do not dissolve it unless after three days or four or five or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it [the fracture] is released after twenty days, according to what appears to you from the solution of the limb, as we said, until when the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh approaches it: add also then in the stricture more than your first stricture; and add also in the swelling of food for the sick, according to what preceded the remembrance of it.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the place of the fracture is already drying out and becoming thinner than it should be: then know that nutrition is forbidden to reach it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Apply the embrocation itself with warm water at every place where you solve it, and let it be for all three days, and alleviate the stricture slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 Through this operation, nutrition flows to the limb, and it is healed quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 But what the foolish restorers do instead of restoring a fractured limb when it should not be restored first, according to what is necessary, and they restore it according to its crookedness, is an error from their operation, and there is great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said that in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I did not see any trace of theirs at all in that, and it is better not to do it.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on making a fracture in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 The species of fractures are diverse, and the forms of it many; and the causes of it are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For from a fracture is that which happens from a blow with a sword; and the blow takes away the bone completely until it reaches the saphec, which is under the bone, just as an ax does in wood; and because of this it is called this species of fracture "Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 The knife cut something of the bone and cut its face, but did not penetrate through the incision to its end; this type of fracture is called Kalan, that is, Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And it is a wound of two kinds of fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from the fracture is one that is a crushing or grinding; and its cause is a blow with a stone, or a fall on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also penetrating, which approaches the cloth that is under the bone; or it is on the surface of the bone; and it is a wound of these two kinds of fractures, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from the fracture is one that is hidden inside the bone in its subtlety (porosity); and it is a small crack; and for this reason this type of fracture is called Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from these (kinds of fractures) is a fracture that occurs due to a fall or blow of a stone and similar things, which cause the bone layer to penetrate inside; and this creates a hollow: as it happens with caldrons of metal when they are struck, and part of them penetrates inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 And this occurs most often in the soft bones of the head, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures (are treated) with splints applied separately; and I will return when reminded of the whole in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We recognize all these types of fractures by examination on it, and investigation of them with probing tools, and removal of corrupted flesh that is on top of them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary type is recognized by the fact that it protrudes from the bone and is scraped off, and is bound over it with a hot iron; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the conditions of the sick person: then, if you see among the conditions that indicate fear, such as cholera vomiting, extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, fainting, acute fever, eye discharge, redness of eyes, and similar conditions in many dispositions, there is no doubt that it will not heal: and if you see conditions that do not frighten you, and hope for recovery: then begin the treatment of it.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded person comes to you, first know that it happens during the winter days: then, it is necessary for you to study the removal of bone before the fourteenth day according to all dispositions.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 And if it is during summer days, then you must hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone from fat becomes rotten, and those conditions that I mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of a bone has already reached the fat touching the brain, and it is with cracks and adhesion: then you must cut the broken and smoothed part according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is to shave the head of the wounded person and scrape above the bone as much as possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the sick one.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If blood flow or a hot abscess happens to you during the scraping of bone: then apply what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is to fill the place with soaked rags in wine and rose oil: and let the wound rest until the abscess settles down, and be safe from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin the treatment and removal of the bone.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And that is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 A method exists, to cut a bone with an incisor of a rigid blade: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Another way to administer the Incisorium after the Incisors wider by a small amount, and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then also administer another Incisorium wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is, that there be with you a number of various Incisoriums; some of which are wider than others, and some of them shorter than others: and they should be at the end of their sharpnesses, and made of Indian iron or bronze: and use them with ease in striking on an Incisorium, so as not to strike the head, and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If however the bone is hard: then it is necessary that you bore around its circumference before you administer Incisoria with Terebris which are not too deep; and they are not called this unless because these do not penetrate beyond the bone's marrow to that which is beyond it, because a Terebra is rounded at the top of what is under the head, sharp like an edge, similar to a small circle, preventing immersion and penetrating the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 And it is suitable for you that you take a large number of those Terebris, each one fitting the thickness of the bone, until you have with you all Terebris of the skull: whose sharp edges' length and width should correspond to the thickness of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the shape of three types of Terebris or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of boring around a broken bone is: that you place the Terebra on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the position of the Terebra to another place and put one that is between every hole with the size of a finger or approximately that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the incisors that which is between every opening in the bone; make this as delicate as you can above it from the edge of tenderness, as we said, until you root out the bone, either with your hand or with some other instruments which you have prepared for this purpose: such as tenaculae and subtle forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And be careful to avoid the Terebrum or the Incisorium from touching the siphac.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you surround the bone by piercing it and it has been separated from the siphac if it is continuous with it and you pull it out, it is necessary that you root and even out the remaining extremity of it in the bone with another similar instrument like the Incisorium.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 However, it should be thin and delicate more than other incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains of the small bones and cartilages; then take these with ease along with that which is at hand among your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after this with linen cloths and the ointments which we have mentioned.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy, entirely remote from fear; this one has been said by Galen and he praised it greatly; and this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 First, it is necessary for you to begin by exposing the bone in the place where the fracture is more violent and more apparent; until when you have exposed this part, and placed under it the extremity of this curved incisor, which has this shape: lenticular.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 And the lenticular part does not cut anything; and the sharp part of it goes in two sides of it in length, as you see; so that the lenticular part is attached to the siphac with the sharp end falling on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike the incisor from one side with a small hammer until you cut the whole bone easily, as it is turned; and you should be careful from the cloth that it does not happen what you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 If the physician were not the most foolish of men, and more ignorant than he should be, nor sleeping, then if something attached to the bone from a fold remained in certain places, it would strike off that part along with the lenticular incisor, and release it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If a bone fracture does not penetrate the flesh and what is to be cut away from the bone remains in it, then there will remain roughness and subtle protrusions; then you must smooth out that roughness, and dig out those subtle protrusions with finer scrapers which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to apply them more conveniently in every place according to the shape to which the operation leads and the fractured bone and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And you must administer it according to your own reasoning, in the first place scraping the bone more widely than those scrapers.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer tool after that one.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease doing this continuously until you reach the point of administering it more narrowly and finer than all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small fissures and subtle fractures, care must be taken according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a matter which does not escape the notice of any who have studied this art, and it remains over what we wrote and showed about large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If the flesh is detached when you scrape the bone, then you must take a piece of linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and soak it in rose oil and place it over the wound opening.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another cloth, doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on the first cloth: and do that as easily as possible without burdening the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then apply a broad bandage over it: and do not tighten it unless in such quantity as holds the wound only: and leave it with this care for one day or two until you are assured of being free from hot suppuration.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it, and apply afterwards medicines with which excessive dryness is required: such as the roots of garlic, and the flour of herbs, and the powder of incense, and aristolochia, and similar ones: and there is, that you make from these medicines a powder, which is to be sprinkled on the wound like those that are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally apply to it every medicine of such a property as to cleanse and not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your skill, that the wound during your treatment is clean: and let there be neither ointment stains nor dirt.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 And let no pus accumulate in it at all: because when pus accumulates on the brain cloth, it corrupts it and rots it, and after that a great evil happens to the sick person: and it has already happened in the head wound, when the bone is cleansed from it, particularly when the care of it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore consider then, if what we have said happens to the sick person, know that it is certainly fatal.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if blackness does not occur except from the medicine that is applied to it, and this medicine has the property to cause it: then you should receive one part from honey, three parts from rose oil, and clean a cloth with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it (the instrument) on the siphac (anus); afterwards take care of it with suitable medicaments until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 On the restoration of the nose when it is fractured.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not fractured except when both its upper parts are fractured at once, or only one of them; this is because it has two bones above: since below it is cartilaginous and does not break, but occurs only in attrition, curvature, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of its two parts is fractured, then it is necessary to insert a small finger into the nose opening and equalize the fracture with your index and thumb on the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; this should be done skillfully with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And beware that the pain does not worsen as a result of your operation on the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and the finger does not reach it; then it is necessary to equalize the extremity of the radius, where there is a slight swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in both parts (of the nose), then do the same (as above); and proceed with the restoration of it on the first day of the fracture if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then wait for the seventh or tenth day in a warm room with plasters.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of linen from a flax cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two pieces of linen if the fracture is in both parts: and let there be enough thickness in the linen to fill the nose opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some ancient restorers have said that the linen should be soaked in butter and changed daily.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But I do not see it that way; on the contrary, it seems necessary to me that the linen should be soaked in egg white, made with milled flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then let the sutures (or ligatures) be removed when the bone is set and the cartilage hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a feather of a goose is introduced into the nose instead of a ligature; and it is wrapped in a soft cloth over it: so that it holds the broken part of the nose more strongly, and does not prevent it from being inspired.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this matter is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish, do that; and if you wish, do it with a ligature.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose should happen to occur again while treating a warm boil, pack the nose with beeswax or with wax soaked in rose oil, or a little with dyaquilon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 If the boil is not warm, then it is necessary to pack it with sisa flour and turmeric powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft wad on top of it and do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the bones of the nose are broken in a small fracture or crushed, then it is necessary to cut above them and remove them with instruments suitable for the task.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then suture it and take care of it with suitable packing or ointment until it heals.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If a wound occurs between the nose and lip, then treat it with linen cloth, and administer a lead cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on Restoring the Lower Jaw when it is Broken.
Caput V.	 Chapter V:
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is ruptured and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound, then observe if its fracture is only on the outside and it is not broken into two pieces and it bends toward the inside; then recognition of it is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 If the fracture is on the right side of the jaw, insert your left index finger into the weak jaw; similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, insert your right index finger; and push the swelling of the fracture towards the outside with ease using your other hand from the inner part of the bone properly, and press it evenly.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then it is necessary to administer extension from both sides according to correctness; until possible alignment can be achieved.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If it happens that the teeth have been moved or disrupted; then tie them with a thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place over the broken jaw a piece of lead.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place over it a double cloth and place on the cloth a large well-made awl or a piece of shoe leather equal in length to the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then tie it up above as you have prepared its binding and the application is appropriate until it does not break; and order the patient to rest calmly and quietly; and place his soft foods for him.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you think that something has changed in the shape in some way; then hurry and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then rectify what has changed from it, and plaster it with flour milled powder mixed with egg white or wheat flour after you have removed the lead; and place a soft wool over the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that plaster remains attached to it, and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it be, do not remove it until it heals; or tie up the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is tied many times during three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a warm abscess occurs in the meantime, then administer what we have said many times for its soothing until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if there is a fracture with a wound, take note.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 But if a fragment is separated from the bone, or a cyst: then be careful in this matter, so that you remove those fragments of the cyst with what suits you for their removal from your instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the wound's opening is narrowed, then expand it with a leech according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you have removed the cysts and nothing remains of them, or if the wound's opening is wide: and if not, place over it a plaster that suits for this purpose, and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 [Section heading] On the repair of a Fork-bone (Furculum), when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The furcula (clavicle) is broken most frequently from the anterior part, and its fracture occurs in one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 It can be broken and separated into two, apart from what is known as a stump fracture: it is easier to restore this kind of fracture.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or, it can happen on the bone of the stump fracture: it is more difficult to restore this kind.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or, it can be a fracture accompanied by a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 The operation in this case, when the furcula is broken without a wound, is to have two assistants present. One should hold the broken furcula and the other should stretch out the neck towards that side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then, with your fingers, straighten the fracture so that it takes the proper shape, and there should be no prominence nor hollow in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If more extension is needed, then you must place a small ball under the weak person's pillow, made of cloth or wool; its size should be according to your need; and stretch, lift and move the furcula around the ball with your hand until the fracture is straightened, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the end of the furcula to the outside due to it reaching deep inside, then the weak person should lie on their back; and place a small wooden plank under their shoulder in size; and press the assistant's arm towards the bottom, until the furcula bone is lifted from the depth towards the top; and then straighten the fracture and align it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If you feel a stump from the furcula and it moves, then you should press on it and remove the stump easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it is retained in the bone, then make an incision with one of the instruments you have prepared for this purpose; after placing a tool under the furcula to protect the sifach (sore or inflamed tissue); and the tool is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a cavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to the need for it based on the size of the bone and its proportions.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length [of the wound] should also be, as far as possible, for your operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 It has two ends, as you see: one end is broad, and the other is narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the tear in the wound that you split when removing the sathaiatum bone is broad, and you have scissors at hand: then gather together two lips of the wound with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 If [the tear] is small, or you fear a hot abscess: then fill the wound with cloths and with as many sutures as the size of the wound requires.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If a hot abscess occurs, then soak cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But the suture of a bone without a wound and without a cut is to place plaster made from milled flour with egg white on it.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 Place a soft woolen cloth over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a bladder beneath it, if necessary.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a bloodletting instrument, that is, the Saracenic roll, which should be very long: and its width should be about the length of one palm, or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a double suture on top of the woolen cloth and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take an awl from a thin board whose width is three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then thrust it into the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then thrust the cloth with the awl into the place of the bleeding and the fracture.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the bleeding on the fracture as is customary, and thrust it onto his neck, and under a healthy bladder, and under an unhealthy bladder: and pull it over all parts, and in such a way that the suture holds the fracture tightly: and this is what you must not hide from yourself, and everything, so that the awl does not move away from the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary to look at the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Every time the bandage is softened and you see the splinter being removed, then correct it and tighten the bandage.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick man's sleep on his back, and put a small pillow under his head near his sleep, so that when he is awakened, help may be brought to him from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Then raise the fracture of the collarbone by elevating the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind his arm to his neck: and do not loosen the bandage unless it happens in a place happening due to itching, or from an abscess, for up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face turning towards that (the affected area).
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the compression, and let it remain until it is restored and healed.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the collarbone is compressed and supported for up to twenty days; and sometimes it happens in less time in some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the restoration of the fracture of the spatula (pelvis).
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 A spatula rarely breaks and at its wide place; and it is not broken from it except for its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it breaks from that place and breaks in its middle, and it is not known except by touch; then make an attempt at the preparation of the fracture according to its shape.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And reduce it to its natural form in every possible way using your intelligence.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on it the dust of a mill with egg white, and fine starch, and place above it a small cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on top of it a broad awl from fine wood, according to the size of the spatula, or slightly larger than that.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If however there is a hollow under the awl on the spatula at some place, then fill that hollow with fine starch until the awl descends evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then bind it on top with long linen thread and a tight binding, and securely fix the awl until it cannot be moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And observe the binding every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the binding becomes soft, tighten it and if the awl is moved from its place; let it lie weak on its healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And indeed the spatula is restored within twenty days or within twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number has been completed, then loosen the binding; and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from bones whose crushing or dissolution is not feared.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If however a piece of bone projects and pierces under the skin; then cut through it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as I said for a fracture at the neck of the clavicle from suppuration of an abscess; if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of a chest fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Title VIII. (direct literal translation from Latin)
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 Chest sometimes breaks in the middle of itself, and it happens rarely. (direct literal translation from Latin)
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 The extremities indeed break most often, and they grind down due to accidents. (direct literal translation from Latin)
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.
